item.title: Wind signals lifted as Tropical Storm Ada continues to move away

item.title: FSM president facing probe over unreleased funds for prosecutor's office
item.description: It has been more than two years since the Federated States of Micronesia created the Office of the Independent Prosecutor through a constitutional amendment, but the agency has not been formally established because the funds required to get started are in limbo, according to FSM Independent Prosecutor Lucas M. Cupps.
item.source:markdown: It has been more than two years since the Federated States of Micronesia created the Office of the Independent Prosecutor through a constitutional amendment, but the agency has not been formally established because the funds required to get started are in limbo, according to FSM Independent Prosecutor Lucas M. Cupps.

item.title: Sinulog 2026 draws millions as festival-goers celebrate traditions old and new
item.description: For many, the Sinulog festival is a time to reignite old traditions and for the next generation to create new ones of their own
item.source:markdown: For many, the Sinulog festival is a time to reignite old traditions and for the next generation to create new ones of their own

item.title: Thousands mark 133rd anniversary of Hawaiian Kingdom overthrow
item.description: About 7,000 people joined together at Iolani Palace on Friday to commemorate the 133rd anniversary of the 1893 overthrow of the Hawaiian Kingdom.
item.source:markdown: About 7,000 people joined together at Iolani Palace on Friday to commemorate the 133rd anniversary of the 1893 overthrow of the Hawaiian Kingdom.

item.title: Pahoa man accused of triple homicide might finally be tried after nearly 10 years
item.description: It appears possible a triple homicide case that has stagnated in the Big Island court system for almost a decade will go to trial in the foreseeable future.
item.source:markdown: It appears possible a triple homicide case that has stagnated in the Big Island court system for almost a decade will go to trial in the foreseeable future.

item.title: Hawaii congressional delegation seeks construction of new national cemetery
item.description: Three members of Hawaii’s congressional delegation are proposing a bill to establish a new national veterans cemetery in Hawaii as the state’s only national cemetery is nearing capacity, they announced Friday.
item.source:markdown: Three members of Hawaii’s congressional delegation are proposing a bill to establish a new national veterans cemetery in Hawaii as the state’s only national cemetery is nearing capacity, they announced Friday.

item.title: Trump announces new European tariffs in Greenland standoff; allies outraged
item.description: PALM BEACH, Fla. — President Donald Trump announced in a social media post Saturday morning his latest strategy to get control of Greenland: He is slapping new tariffs on a bloc of European nations until they come to the negotiating table to sell Greenland.
item.source:markdown: PALM BEACH, Fla. — President Donald Trump announced in a social media post Saturday morning his latest strategy to get control of Greenland: He is slapping new tariffs on a bloc of European nations until they come to the negotiating table to sell Greenland.

item.title: County: Bridge to Moku‘ola will be reconstructed
item.description: Hawaii County officials have decided, after consulting with an engineer, that it would be more prudent to reconstruct the pedestrian bridge between Waiakea Peninsula and Moku‘ola (Coconut Island) than to simply repair the damaged section.
item.source:markdown: Hawaii County officials have decided, after consulting with an engineer, that it would be more prudent to reconstruct the pedestrian bridge between Waiakea Peninsula and Moku‘ola (Coconut Island) than to simply repair the damaged section.

item.title: Obituaries for January 18
item.description: Jacinth De Luz Jr. 85, of Waimea died Oct. 30 at home. Born in Waimea, he was retired from the former C. Brewer &Co. a member of Annunciation Catholic Church, Hawaii Army National Guard veteran and hunter, angler, rancher and carpenter. Visitation 10-11 a.m. Saturday, Jan. 31, at Kahilu Town Hall in Waimea. Memorial service at 11 a.m. Lunch to follow. Casual attire. Survived by sons, Jacinth (Yumi) De Luz III of Waikoloa, Jason (Melita) De Luz of Ahualoa, Jerome (Joe Sweeney) De Luz of Portland, Ore., James (Bernadette) De Luz of Waikoloa and Jedfrey (Ryan Johannesen) De Luz of San Francisco; daughter, Lindy (Ed) Guerrero of Waimea; sisters, Betty De Luz of Honokaa and Rose Hatakeyama of Waimea; brother-in-law, Wardell Young of Waimea; sister-in-law, Beverly Young of Kukuihaele; 12 grandchildren and 22 great-grandchildren; nieces, nephews and cousins. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.
item.source:markdown: Jacinth De Luz Jr. 85, of Waimea died Oct. 30 at home. Born in Waimea, he was retired from the former C. Brewer &Co. a member of Annunciation Catholic Church, Hawaii Army National Guard veteran and hunter, angler, rancher and carpenter. Survived by sons, Jacinth (Yumi) De Luz III of Waikoloa, Jason (Melita) De Luz of Ahualoa, Jerome (Joe Sweeney) De Luz of Portland, Ore., James (Bernadette) De Luz of Waikoloa and Jedfrey (Ryan Johannesen) De Luz of San Francisco; daughter, Lindy (Ed) Guerrero of Waimea; sisters, Betty De Luz of Honokaa and Rose Hatakeyama of Waimea; brother-in-law, Wardell Young of Waimea; sister-in-law, Beverly Young of Kukuihaele; 12 grandchildren and 22 great-grandchildren; nieces, nephews and cousins. item.title: World leaders consider joining Trump’s ‘Board of Peace’ for Gaza
item.description: JERUSALEM — World leaders Saturday were weighing whether to join President Donald Trump’s “Board of Peace,” as the Trump administration tries to move ahead with its ambitious postwar vision for the Gaza Strip.
item.source:markdown: JERUSALEM — World leaders Saturday were weighing whether to join President Donald Trump’s “Board of Peace,” as the Trump administration tries to move ahead with its ambitious postwar vision for the Gaza Strip.

item.title: Syria advances on Kurdish-Held areas as Washington urges restraint
item.description: BEIRUT — Syrian government troops advanced into Kurdish-held territory in the north Saturday, seizing key towns and sparking fresh clashes that threatened to unravel a once-promising political agreement meant to reunify a fractured nation.
item.source:markdown: BEIRUT — Syrian government troops advanced into Kurdish-held territory in the north Saturday, seizing key towns and sparking fresh clashes that threatened to unravel a once-promising political agreement meant to reunify a fractured nation.

item.title: NASA’s giant rocket begins slow roll toward Artemis II moon voyage
item.description: Reid Wiseman, a NASA astronaut selected in 2011, said Saturday morning that a few days ago he looked up and saw the crescent moon in the light of the sunrise. He thought about the far side of the moon — the part that is always hidden from Earth.
item.source:markdown: Reid Wiseman, a NASA astronaut selected in 2011, said Saturday morning that a few days ago he looked up and saw the crescent moon in the light of the sunrise. He thought about the far side of the moon — the part that is always hidden from Earth.

item.title: The House Republican majority is down to almost nothing
item.description: A surprise resignation and a sudden death have left House Republican leaders starting the new session of Congress with their already slim majority down to the bare minimum of 218 seats.
item.source:markdown: A surprise resignation and a sudden death have left House Republican leaders starting the new session of Congress with their already slim majority down to the bare minimum of 218 seats.

item.title: ‘Yankee, go home’: Greenlanders protest Trump’s takeover plans
item.description: NUUK, Greenland — For the first time since President Donald Trump renewed his campaign to take over Greenland, people across the Arctic island braved the freezing temperatures and took to the icy streets on Saturday in coordinated protests.
item.source:markdown: NUUK, Greenland — For the first time since President Donald Trump renewed his campaign to take over Greenland, people across the Arctic island braved the freezing temperatures and took to the icy streets on Saturday in coordinated protests.

item.title: After Renee Good killing, derisive term for white women spreads on the far right
item.description: In the days since a federal agent killed Renee Good in Minneapolis, Republican officials and conservative commentators have called the 37-year-old white woman “very violent,” a “deranged lunatic woman” and a “domestic terrorist.”
item.source:markdown: In the days since a federal agent killed Renee Good in Minneapolis, Republican officials and conservative commentators have called the 37-year-old white woman “very violent,” a “deranged lunatic woman” and a “domestic terrorist.”

item.title: $2 rental batteries are helping to power South Africa

item.title: Steves: Car-free and carefree on the Greek island of Hydra
item.description: The island of Hydra — less than two hours south of Athens by ferry — offers the ideal Greek island experience, and doesn’t require a long journey across the Aegean. But those who come here with an agenda should be warned: This is the kind of place that makes you want to buy a bottle of ouzo and toss your itinerary into the sea.
item.source:markdown: The island of Hydra — less than two hours south of Athens by ferry — offers the ideal Greek island experience, and doesn’t require a long journey across the Aegean. But those who come here with an agenda should be warned: This is the kind of place that makes you want to buy a bottle of ouzo and toss your itinerary into the sea.

item.title: Volcano Watch: 1969 Maunaulu eruption had 12 lava fountaining episodes
item.description: Last week’s “Volcano Watch” article reviewed the lava fountaining eruption of Kilauea Iki in 1959. This week, we’ll continue looking back in time at the next episodic lava fountaining eruption in Kilauea’s history: the Maunaulu eruption that occurred a decade later, in 1969.
item.source:markdown: Last week’s “Volcano Watch” article reviewed the lava fountaining eruption of Kilauea Iki in 1959. This week, we’ll continue looking back in time at the next episodic lava fountaining eruption in Kilauea’s history: the Maunaulu eruption that occurred a decade later, in 1969.

item.title: US lawmakers meet with Danish prime minister on Greenland
item.description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark — A bipartisan group of lawmakers from Capitol Hill sought to reassure Denmark and Greenland on Friday that they supported Denmark’s control of Greenland despite President Donald Trump’s vow to seize it “one way or another.” But there appeared to be little progress in solving what has become a crisis in Denmark and Europe more broadly.
item.source:markdown: COPENHAGEN, Denmark — A bipartisan group of lawmakers from Capitol Hill sought to reassure Denmark and Greenland on Friday that they supported Denmark’s control of Greenland despite President Donald Trump’s vow to seize it “one way or another.” But there appeared to be little progress in solving what has become a crisis in Denmark and Europe more broadly.

item.title: Trump Store to close as sales falter, with no election battles ahead
item.description: Nestled in a strip mall in suburban Philadelphia, The Trump Store is hard to miss with its all-caps sign in bold next to a photo of President Donald Trump hugging the American flag. But after six years of drawing MAGA supporters from all over, the 800-square-foot store, which sports everything from hats and watches emblazoned with the president’s name is closing.
item.source:markdown: Nestled in a strip mall in suburban Philadelphia, The Trump Store is hard to miss with its all-caps sign in bold next to a photo of President Donald Trump hugging the American flag. But after six years of drawing MAGA supporters from all over, the 800-square-foot store, which sports everything from hats and watches emblazoned with the president’s name is closing.

item.title: Russian strikes force Kyiv schools to close amid rolling blackouts
item.description: KYIV, Ukraine — As millions of Ukrainians endure the winter cold amid blackouts caused by repeated Russian strikes on power plants, Kyiv authorities announced Friday that schools in the capital would close until February — one of the most severe disruptions yet to daily life.
item.source:markdown: KYIV, Ukraine — As millions of Ukrainians endure the winter cold amid blackouts caused by repeated Russian strikes on power plants, Kyiv authorities announced Friday that schools in the capital would close until February — one of the most severe disruptions yet to daily life.

item.title: No link between acetaminophen in pregnancy and autism, a new study finds
item.description: A scientific review of 43 studies on acetaminophen use during pregnancy concluded that there was no evidence that the painkiller increased the risk of autism or other neurodevelopmental disorders.
item.source:markdown: A scientific review of 43 studies on acetaminophen use during pregnancy concluded that there was no evidence that the painkiller increased the risk of autism or other neurodevelopmental disorders.

item.title: Martin Luther King Jr. Day 2026 will be celebrated in the territory
item.description:
By 
Samoa News staff
reporters@samoanews.com

Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA — Martin Luther King Jr. Day, Monday, January 19, 2026, will be observed as a public holiday in American Samoa. This day provides an opportunity to honor the life and enduring legacy of Dr. King whose leadership and unwavering commitment to equality, justice, and community service continue to inspire us all.

 Governor Pulaali i Nikolao Pula said in a statement yesterday, “As we observe this day, I encourage everyone to reflect on his values and consider ways we can each contribute to building a stronger, more compassionate community.

Congresswoman Uifa’atali Amata released the following statement in recognition of the day:

“Martin Luther King Jr. gave our nation a lasting example of moral courage rooted in faith, love of neighbor, and respect for human dignity. His leadership demonstrated that meaningful change is achieved not through division or force, but through persuasion, perseverance, and peaceful action.

“Dr. King’s speeches and writings continue to speak clearly across generations because they appeal to our highest ideals — equality under the law, opportunity for all, and unity grounded in mutual respect. His life reminds us that standing for what is right requires both conviction and compassion.

“As we honor the legacy of Martin Luther King Jr., we are reminded that the work of building a stronger nation is never finished. His example calls each of us to act with integrity, to treat one another with kindness, and to pursue justice in a way that brings people together, not apart.”

 All government offices will be closed, and normal operations will be suspended for the day. Employees of the American Samoa Government who are not required to perform essential services are excused from duty. Those whose services are required will receive holiday compensation in accordance with applicable laws and regulations.

Samoa News will not publish Monday in honor of MLK Day and our office will be closed. We’ll be back on Tuesday. 

Have a safe and peaceful 3-day holiday — Martin Luther King Day is designated as a day of service. 

Section: 
Local News
Tags: 
MLK day
item.source:markdown:
[![MLK Banner](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/field/image/mlk_banner.jpg?itok=5fTulVqR)](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_normal_image/public/field/image/mlk_banner.jpg?itok=DPmjYaN1)
By
Samoa News staff
reporters@samoanews.com
_Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA —_ Martin Luther King Jr. Day, Monday, January 19, 2026, will be observed as a public holiday in American Samoa. This day provides an opportunity to honor the life and enduring legacy of Dr. King whose leadership and unwavering commitment to equality, justice, and community service continue to inspire us all.
Governor Pulaali i Nikolao Pula said in a statement yesterday, “As we observe this day, I encourage everyone to reflect on his values and consider ways we can each contribute to building a stronger, more compassionate community.
Congresswoman Uifa’atali Amata released the following statement in recognition of the day:
“Martin Luther King Jr. gave our nation a lasting example of moral courage rooted in faith, love of neighbor, and respect for human dignity. His leadership demonstrated that meaningful change is achieved not through division or force, but through persuasion, perseverance, and peaceful action.
“Dr. King’s speeches and writings continue to speak clearly across generations because they appeal to our highest ideals — equality under the law, opportunity for all, and unity grounded in mutual respect. His life reminds us that standing for what is right requires both conviction and compassion.
“As we honor the legacy of Martin Luther King Jr., we are reminded that the work of building a stronger nation is never finished. His example calls each of us to act with integrity, to treat one another with kindness, and to pursue justice in a way that brings people together, not apart.”
All government offices will be closed, and normal operations will be suspended for the day. Employees of the American Samoa Government who are not required to perform essential services are excused from duty. Those whose services are required will receive holiday compensation in accordance with applicable laws and regulations.
Samoa News will not publish Monday in honor of MLK Day and our office will be closed. We’ll be back on Tuesday.
Have a safe and peaceful 3-day holiday — Martin Luther King Day is designated as a day of service.

item.title: Trump threatens to use military over Minnesota anti-ICE protests
item.description: WASHINGTON — President Donald Trump threatened on Thursday to invoke the Insurrection Act to deploy military forces in Minnesota after days of angry protests over a surge in immigration agents on the streets of Minneapolis. Confrontations between residents and federal officers have become increasingly tense after an Immigration and Customs Enforcement agent fatally shot a U.S. citizen, Renee Good, in a car eight days ago in Minneapolis, and the protests have spread to other cities.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — President Donald Trump threatened on Thursday to invoke the Insurrection Act to deploy military forces in Minnesota after days of angry protests over a surge in immigration agents on the streets of Minneapolis. item.title: US farm economy shows widening cracks as costs rise, jobs vanish
item.description: CHICAGO — Across the U.S. farm belt, these have become depressing times. Farmers are facing another season of low prices, high costs and difficult decisions about how — or whether — to keep operating. Banks are cutting off some growers just as they urgently need cash. Thousands of workers are losing jobs as meatpacking plants close and farm equipment makers scale back.
item.source:markdown: CHICAGO — Across the U.S. farm belt, these have become depressing times. Farmers are facing another season of low prices, high costs and difficult decisions about how — or whether — to keep operating. Banks are cutting off some growers just as they urgently need cash. Thousands of workers are losing jobs as meatpacking plants close and farm equipment makers scale back.

item.title: Europeans send troops to Greenland as Trump presses claim
item.description: NUUK/COPENHAGEN — European countries sent small numbers of military personnel to Greenland on Thursday as Denmark said it was pressing on with plans for a “larger and more permanent” NATO presence to secure the island coveted by President Donald Trump. The modest European deployments, meant to help Denmark prepare military exercises, sent a strong message of support a day after a meeting of officials from the U.S., Denmark and Greenland failed to reach any breakthrough on the impasse. After that meeting, Trump repeated his assertion that Denmark could not be relied upon to protect its autonomous territory, Greenland, if Russia or China ever wanted to occupy it. Trump says the strategically located and mineral-rich island is vital to U.S. security and has not ruled out the use of force to take it. Greenland and Denmark say it is not for sale and that threats of force are reckless.
item.source:markdown: NUUK/COPENHAGEN — European countries sent small numbers of military personnel to Greenland on Thursday as Denmark said it was pressing on with plans for a “larger and more permanent” NATO presence to secure the island coveted by President Donald Trump. The modest European deployments, meant to help Denmark prepare military exercises, sent a strong message of support a day after a meeting of officials from the U.S., Denmark and Greenland failed to reach any breakthrough on the impasse. After that meeting, Trump repeated his assertion that Denmark could not be relied upon to protect its autonomous territory, Greenland, if Russia or China ever wanted to occupy it. Trump says the strategically located and mineral-rich island is vital to U.S. security and has not ruled out the use of force to take it. Greenland and Denmark say it is not for sale and that threats of force are reckless.

item.title: Launching Le Vasa and historic agreement with Google
item.description:
By 
Samoa News staff
reporters@samoanews.com

Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA — Samoa's Prime Minister Laaulialemalietoa Leuatea Polataivao Fosi Schmidt is visiting American Samoa this week as a special guest for the launch of the Le Vasa submarine cable with a historic agreement signing with Google, fostering stronger digital connectivity and collaboration between the two Samoas. The Prime Minister was welcomed by  Governor Pulaalii Nikolao Pula upon arrival.

The Prime Minister’s delegation includes the Minister of Communications and Information Technology Hon. Agaseata Tanuvasa Valelio Peto, Chief Executive Officer of M.C.I.T. Leasoiloafaleuplou Ronnie Aiolupotea, Chief Executive Officer of the Ministry of Prime Minister and Cabinet Agafili Tomaimanō Shem Leo, Acting Police Commissioner Leiātaua Samuelu Afamasaga, and Apulu Lance Polu.

The Prime Minister, Gov. Pulaali’i and their advisors will be holding discussions with Google officials.

BACKGROUND

The Le Vasa cable and forthcoming collaboration with Google was publicly announced by Governor Pulaali’i’s during his State of the Territory Address delivered on Monday, Jan. 12, 2026, at the opening of the 3rd Regular Session of the 39th Legislature of American Samoa. It was highlighted as one of his administration’s most important economic developments to help diversify the local economy.

Senate President Tuaolo Manaia Fruean, in his response to Gov. Pulaali’i’s on behalf of the Fono, pointed out that while ARPA funding is expected to cover $15 million of the costs for the critical Google cable installation project, the total project budget is $45 million.

He said this raises significant concerns about the remaining $30 million needed to complete the project, prompting Tuaolo to question from where the additional funds will come.

 

Section: 
Local News
Tags: 
Le Vasa submarine cable
item.source:markdown:
[![Governor and Samoa PM](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/field/image/gov_pula_pm_schmidt.jpg?itok=qFrGsr7k)](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_normal_image/public/field/image/gov_pula_pm_schmidt.jpg?itok=lIGNwrjd)
By
Samoa News staff
reporters@samoanews.com
_Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA —_ Samoa's Prime Minister Laaulialemalietoa Leuatea Polataivao Fosi Schmidt is visiting American Samoa this week as a special guest for the launch of the Le Vasa submarine cable with a historic agreement signing with Google, fostering stronger digital connectivity and collaboration between the two Samoas. The Prime Minister was welcomed by Governor Pulaalii Nikolao Pula upon arrival.
The Prime Minister’s delegation includes the Minister of Communications and Information Technology Hon. Agaseata Tanuvasa Valelio Peto, Chief Executive Officer of M.C.I.T. Leasoiloafaleuplou Ronnie Aiolupotea, Chief Executive Officer of the Ministry of Prime Minister and Cabinet Agafili Tomaimanō Shem Leo, Acting Police Commissioner Leiātaua Samuelu Afamasaga, and Apulu Lance Polu.
The Prime Minister, Gov. Pulaali’i and their advisors will be holding discussions with Google officials.
**BACKGROUND**
The Le Vasa cable and forthcoming collaboration with Google was publicly announced by Governor Pulaali’i’s during his State of the Territory Address delivered on Monday, Jan. 12, 2026, at the opening of the 3rd Regular Session of the 39th Legislature of American Samoa. It was highlighted as one of his administration’s most important economic developments to help diversify the local economy.
Senate President Tuaolo Manaia Fruean, in his response to Gov. Pulaali’i’s on behalf of the Fono, pointed out that while ARPA funding is expected to cover $15 million of the costs for the critical Google cable installation project, the total project budget is $45 million.
He said this raises significant concerns about the remaining $30 million needed to complete the project, prompting Tuaolo to question from where the additional funds will come.

item.title: “A Skill for Life”: How a seamstress is fighting unemployment in Lae
item.description:
In a city where jobs are scarce, a mother of five from Manus is helping Lae residents learn skills that can put food on the table.

Shilla Francis is running a beginner sewing training at the Timber College area in Lae, teaching participants how to make meri blouses, mission kolos and sun dresses.

item.title: PNGRFL launches first gender strategy for rugby league
item.description:
The Papua New Guinea Rugby Football League (PNGRFL) has announced its inaugural gender strategy, which will work to advance gender equality in rugby league through an inclusive, safe, and empowering environment that enables women, men, girls and boys to participate and lead at all levels of the game.

The strategy’s creation has been supported by the Australian Government through the PNG Rugby League Pathways Development Program, which is working in partnership with PNG rugby league stakeholders to build stronger foundations for young women’s and men’s active participation and high performance in rugby league.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post PNGRFL launches first gender strategy for rugby league appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/PNG-RFL.png?w=800)
The Papua New Guinea Rugby Football League (PNGRFL) has announced its inaugural gender strategy, which will work to advance gender equality in rugby league through an inclusive, safe, and empowering environment that enables women, men, girls and boys to participate and lead at all levels of the game.
The strategy’s creation has been supported by the Australian Government through the PNG Rugby League Pathways Development Program, which is working in partnership with PNG rugby league stakeholders to build stronger foundations for young women’s and men’s active participation and high performance in rugby league.

item.title: How ICE crackdowns set off a resistance in American cities
item.description: It began in Los Angeles, in Signal chats and strategy sessions on Zoom. Last year, as immigration raids proliferated throughout the city, Latino activists and neighbors began organizing a response, monitoring for Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents along sidewalks and in Home Depot parking lots and texting their networks when they spotted an arrest underway.

Last year, as immigration raids proliferated throughout the city, Latino activists and neighbors began organizing a response, monitoring for Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents along sidewalks and in Home Depot parking lots and texting their networks when they spotted an arrest underway.

item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — President Donald Trump reiterated on Wednesday that the U.S. needs Greenland and that Denmark cannot be relied upon to protect the island, even as he said that “something will work out” with respect to the future governance of the Danish overseas territory.

item.description: The American Civil Liberties Union of Hawaii filed a habeas corpus petition Tuesday in U.S. District Court seeking the release of a 42-year-old Captain Cook man who has been incarcerated without charges or bail at the Federal Detention Center in Honolulu.

item.title: Hilo police officers plead not guilty to offenses related to search of a suspect
item.description: Two Hawaii Police Department officers pleaded not guilty Wednesday afternoon to charges they allegedly violated an arrestee’s constitutional protections during a search of the individual’s belongings.

item.title: Obituaries for January 15
item.description: Judy Marie Duarte, 73, of Napoopoo died Dec. 18 at Kona Community Hospital. Born in Kealakekua, she was a homemaker and coffee farmer in Holualoa. Visitation 9-10 a.m. Saturday, Feb. 14, at St. Michael’s Catholic Church in Kailua-Kona. Mass at 10 a.m. Lunch to follow at Kona Imin Center in Holualoa. Burial noon Wednesday, Feb. 18, at Kona Memorial Park in Holualoa. Casual attire; flowers welcome. Survived by sons, Clifford W. Denis Jr. of Holualoa, Darren Denis of Napoopoo and Chad Denis of Holualoa; daughter, Sherry Ann Denis of Kalaoa; brothers, William Duarte Jr., Alan Duarte and Wayne Duarte of Holualoa; sister, Darlene Duarte of Holualoa; grandchildren and great-grandchildren; nieces, nephews and cousins. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.

item.title: Trump’s greenlight for Nvidia AI chips to China draws fire from lawmakers, former officials
item.description: WASHINGTON — U.S. lawmakers and former officials on Wednesday questioned President Donald Trump’s decision to allow Nvidia to sell its second most powerful AI chips in China, arguing the move erodes America’s AI edge and threatens to electrify Beijing’s military.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — U.S. lawmakers and former officials on Wednesday questioned President Donald Trump’s decision to allow Nvidia to sell its second most powerful AI chips in China, arguing the move erodes America’s AI edge and threatens to electrify Beijing’s military.

item.title: China announces record trade surplus as its exports flood world markets
item.description: BEIJING — China announced on Wednesday the world’s largest trade surplus ever, even adjusting for inflation, as a tsunami of exports flooded markets around the world last year.
item.source:markdown: BEIJING — China announced on Wednesday the world’s largest trade surplus ever, even adjusting for inflation, as a tsunami of exports flooded markets around the world last year.

item.title: Crane falls on passenger train in Thailand, killing at least 31
item.description: BANGKOK — A crane fell on a train with about 200 passengers and crew members aboard in northeastern Thailand on Wednesday, killing at least 31 people and injuring dozens of others, the Thai Health Ministry said.
item.source:markdown: BANGKOK — A crane fell on a train with about 200 passengers and crew members aboard in northeastern Thailand on Wednesday, killing at least 31 people and injuring dozens of others, the Thai Health Ministry said.

item.title: US to suspend immigrant visa processing for 75 nations, State Department says
item.description: WASHINGTON — President Donald Trump’s administration is suspending processing for immigrant visas for applicants from 75 countries, a State Department spokesperson said on Wednesday, as part of Washington’s intensifying immigration crackdown.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — President Donald Trump’s administration is suspending processing for immigrant visas for applicants from 75 countries, a State Department spokesperson said on Wednesday, as part of Washington’s intensifying immigration crackdown.

item.title: Supreme Court backs police entry without warrant in emergencies
item.description: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday said law enforcement officials had flexibility to enter a home without a warrant based on reports that someone inside might need emergency help, a decision with implications for police tactics and the expectation of privacy in one’s home.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday said law enforcement officials had flexibility to enter a home without a warrant based on reports that someone inside might need emergency help, a decision with implications for police tactics and the expectation of privacy in one’s home.

item.title: FBI searches Washington Post journalist’s home in national security probe
item.description: WASHINGTON — FBI agents searched a Washington Post reporter’s home on Wednesday as part of an investigation into sharing secret government information, officials said, in a move that press advocates said threatened journalistic freedom.

item.title: Mire ready to lead
item.description:
As the SP PNG Hunters grind through the second block of 2026 preseason training, a familiar face is stepping into a new light. Josh Mire, a player who has spent the last few seasons being shifted across the park, has declared that 2026 is the year he returns to his roots, and takes charge of a young squad.

With a significant portion of last year’s roster moving on to new opportunities, Mire finds himself as one of the senior heads in a camp filled with fresh faces. For Mire, the objective is clear: reclaim the number 6 or 7 jersey and lead from the front.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Mire ready to lead appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Hanuabada no longer a ‘No-Go Zone’ as Police return, Faiya-Wara Ban after Seven Years
item.description:
For the first time in seven years, police sirens are once again echoing through the heart of Hanuabada village.

The Motu Koitabu Assembly (MKA) has officially declared that the historic stand-off in the village against police is no longer a “no-go zone” for law enforcement.

item.title: Rosso urged citizens to surrender Illegal guns
item.description:
As Prime Minister James Marape departed for the World Economic Forum in Switzerland, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for lands and immigration, John Rosso will serve as the Acting Prime minister, continue to address the issue of illegal guns in the country with the support of the police and defense forces.

John Rosso has raised a stern warning to citizens holding illegal weapons to surrender them immediately or face serious consequences saying it is time to hand in your guns.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: PM Marape to attend 56th World Economic Forum Annual Meeting in Switzerland
item.description:
PRIME Minister James Marape will join world leaders from around the globe to attend the World Economic Forum which will convene its 56th Annual Meeting from 19 to 23 January 2026 in Davos-Klosters, Switzerland, bringing together close to 3,000 cross-sector leaders from over 130 countries under the theme A Spirit of Dialogue.

Marking record levels of governmental participation, 400 top political leaders – including close to 65 heads of state and government and six of the G7’s leaders – are expected to take part, alongside nearly 850 of the world’s top CEOs and chairpersons, and almost 100 leading unicorns and technology pioneers.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post PM Marape to attend 56th World Economic Forum Annual Meeting in Switzerland appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: TAOA hot meal program resumes
item.description:
Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA — TAOA's hot meal program is resuming this week, beginning Wednesday (Jan 14, 2026), and continuing through Thursday (Jan 15, 2026) and Friday (Jan 16, 2026) at regular locations.

For Aunuu next week: the food distribution schedule will resume on the usual days.

For the rest of Tutuila: West Coast (Monday, Wednesday, Friday) East Coast (Tuesday, Thursday, Friday).

Samoa News understands the meal program has not been happening since December 2025 due to the participating food vendors not willing to continue because they had not being paid in a timely manner — with arrears of at least 3- 5 months. While partial payments have since been made, the government is also insisting that food vendors must fulfill their contractual obligations.

Samoa News was told that the current contracts for the food vendors run through May 2026, but, they currently have no legal assurance they will be paid in a timely manner. New contracts will allegedly have a “pay by” schedule included to avoid this type of issue, and the food vendors say they will ‘wait & see’.

Food vendors have long been frustrated with the delayed payments, saying they cannot afford, as small businesses, to carry the cost of goods, including the overheads to deliver the hot meals for the program for an unlimited amount of time. They also point to the hot meal program being fully funded by the federal government and don’t understand why the more than 45-day payment delay.

Section: 
Local News
Tags: 
taoa hot meal progrm

item.title: State of the Territory Address focuses on economic development efforts
item.description:
Fono response notes Admin’s lack of transparency
By 
Samoa News staff
reporters@samoanews.com

Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA — Governor Pulaalii Nikolao Pula delivered the State of the Territory Address on Monday, Jan. 12, 2026, when the 39th Legislature of American Samoa convened its Third Regular Session at the Gov. H. Rex Lee Auditorium. Following the Governor’s address, Senate President Tuaolo Manaia Fruean spoke on behalf of the Fono, offering a counter balance to the governor’s highlights of his admin’s economic development efforts.

Attending the event were members of the Senate and House of Representatives,  which included the President of the Senate Tuaolo, Speaker of the House Savali Talavou Ale; and, Lieutenant Governor Pulumataala Ae Ae Jr., Cabinet members, and honorary guests.

Invocation for the event was offered by Reverend Elder Faigata Manase of CCCAS Malaeloa, with their choir's beautiful voices resonating throughout the event.

STATE OF THE TERRITORY ADDRESS

In his Address, Governor Pulaalii highlighted economic development in the territory as their top priority, pointing to their efforts to diversify the economy, strengthen local businesses, and build long-term resilience following the COVID-19 pandemic. He stated that federal recovery funding has been strategically used to improve infrastructure and public services, and commended the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) Office and partner agencies for their teamwork and progress.

In particular, Gov. Pualaali’i noted a forthcoming collaboration with Google —the "Le Vasa" cable — with it in the works to improve internet reliability, reduce service disruptions, and will expand access to online education, healthcare, and digital services.

In closing, Governor Pulaali’i encouraged the three branches of government — Judiciary, Legislature and Executive to continue collaboration, responsible leadership, and service to the people of American Samoa. He emphasized that lasting progress is achieved through unity and a shared dedication to building a stronger future for the Territory.

“Let us have a great year of love, respect, and hope,” the governor concluded.

FONO RESPONSE

The Senate President’s response on behalf of the Fono expressed concern that legislators had not yet received any substantive documentation or evidence to support the numerous accomplishments cited by the governor in his address. He said the State of the Territorial Comprehensive Report which should be available in the coming weeks would allow the Fono to respond accordingly.

(The State of the Territorial Comprehensive Report comprises detailed information of the progress from all ASG departments.)

Tuaolo continued that to date, no new revenue measures or financial proposals have been submitted for the Fono's review and approval. This lack of transparency, he said, raises questions about fiscal responsibility and legislative oversight, both crucial to maintaining the integrity of government operations.

In light of these issues, Tuaolo urged the government to explore new revenue sources, including the possibility of introducing sales taxes, to ensure the long-term sustainability of vital government services and infrastructure.

In addition to revenue concerns, Tuaolo reminded attendees that funding from the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) is expected to expire at the end of 2026, prompting urgent consideration of the territory's financial strategies.

He further pointed out that while ARPA funding is expected to cover $15 million of the costs for the critical Google cable installation project, the total project budget is $45 million. This raises significant concerns about the remaining $30 million needed to complete the project, prompting Tuaolo to question from where the additional funds will come.

Another issue raised by Tuaolo concerned the immigration bond for foreign nationals seeking to reside in American Samoa.

He urged the Attorney General to consider raising the bond to $10,000, given the increasing number of immigrants arriving in the territory, which has implications for local resources and community dynamics.

BACKGROUND

In November, the Attorney General’s office announced new immigration bond fees, which have significantly affected fees across various countries. These new regulations have led to bond amounts doubling for many countries, while approximately 30 others will retain their existing lower bond levels.

Notably, China's immigration bond remains capped at $2,300, while in contrast, Portugal has the highest bond fees exceeding $5,000, followed by Iran, Israel, and Slovenia, each with bond amounts surpassing $4,000.

Section: 
Local News
Tags: 
STATE OF THE TERRITORY ADDRESS
item.source:markdown:
Fono response notes Admin’s lack of transparency
[![GOVT LEADERS](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/field/image/govt_leaders.jpg?itok=ac5wRI4R)](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_normal_image/public/field/image/govt_leaders.jpg?itok=l1Fza-b6)
By
Samoa News staff
reporters@samoanews.com
_Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA —_ Governor Pulaalii Nikolao Pula delivered the State of the Territory Address on Monday, Jan. 12, 2026, when the 39th Legislature of American Samoa convened its Third Regular Session at the Gov. H. Rex Lee Auditorium. Following the Governor’s address, Senate President Tuaolo Manaia Fruean spoke on behalf of the Fono, offering a counter balance to the governor’s highlights of his admin’s economic development efforts.
Attending the event were members of the Senate and House of Representatives, which included the President of the Senate Tuaolo, Speaker of the House Savali Talavou Ale; and, Lieutenant Governor Pulumataala Ae Ae Jr., Cabinet members, and honorary guests.
Invocation for the event was offered by Reverend Elder Faigata Manase of CCCAS Malaeloa, with their choir's beautiful voices resonating throughout the event.
**STATE OF THE TERRITORY ADDRESS**
In his Address, Governor Pulaalii highlighted economic development in the territory as their top priority, pointing to their efforts to diversify the economy, strengthen local businesses, and build long-term resilience following the COVID-19 pandemic. He stated that federal recovery funding has been strategically used to improve infrastructure and public services, and commended the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) Office and partner agencies for their teamwork and progress.
In particular, Gov. Pualaali’i noted a forthcoming collaboration with Google —the "Le Vasa" cable — with it in the works to improve internet reliability, reduce service disruptions, and will expand access to online education, healthcare, and digital services.
In closing, Governor Pulaali’i encouraged the three branches of government — Judiciary, Legislature and Executive to continue collaboration, responsible leadership, and service to the people of American Samoa. He emphasized that lasting progress is achieved through unity and a shared dedication to building a stronger future for the Territory.
“Let us have a great year of love, respect, and hope,” the governor concluded.
**FONO RESPONSE**
The Senate President’s response on behalf of the Fono expressed concern that legislators had not yet received any substantive documentation or evidence to support the numerous accomplishments cited by the governor in his address. He said the State of the Territorial Comprehensive Report which should be available in the coming weeks would allow the Fono to respond accordingly.
_(The State of the Territorial Comprehensive Report comprises detailed information of the progress from all ASG departments.)_
Tuaolo continued that to date, no new revenue measures or financial proposals have been submitted for the Fono's review and approval. This lack of transparency, he said, raises questions about fiscal responsibility and legislative oversight, both crucial to maintaining the integrity of government operations.
In light of these issues, Tuaolo urged the government to explore new revenue sources, including the possibility of introducing sales taxes, to ensure the long-term sustainability of vital government services and infrastructure.
In addition to revenue concerns, Tuaolo reminded attendees that funding from the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) is expected to expire at the end of 2026, prompting urgent consideration of the territory's financial strategies.
He further pointed out that while ARPA funding is expected to cover $15 million of the costs for the critical Google cable installation project, the total project budget is $45 million. This raises significant concerns about the remaining $30 million needed to complete the project, prompting Tuaolo to question from where the additional funds will come.
Another issue raised by Tuaolo concerned the immigration bond for foreign nationals seeking to reside in American Samoa.
He urged the Attorney General to consider raising the bond to $10,000, given the increasing number of immigrants arriving in the territory, which has implications for local resources and community dynamics.
**BACKGROUND**
In November, the Attorney General’s office announced new immigration bond fees, which have significantly affected fees across various countries. These new regulations have led to bond amounts doubling for many countries, while approximately 30 others will retain their existing lower bond levels.
Notably, China's immigration bond remains capped at $2,300, while in contrast, Portugal has the highest bond fees exceeding $5,000, followed by Iran, Israel, and Slovenia, each with bond amounts surpassing $4,000.

item.title: Contract signed for upgrading key Chabai-Tonn road in Bougainville
item.description:
A major infrastructure contract has been signed to upgrade a 10-kilometer section of the Bougainville Highway, promising improved connectivity and travel times for local communities.

The agreement, signed between the Department of Works & Highways (DOWH), the Autonomous Bougainville Government (ABG), and Raibro Construction Limited, covers the sealing and upgrading of the road from Chabbai Junction to Tonn.

item.title: PC Online Tidbits
item.description:
Finally, the major banks have spoken out about the pending grey listing of PNG financial institutions by FATF. Most welcome the move as they believe it will bring major reforms to the sector. But the ball is in their court. They are the ones who need to know their customers and shut down the money laundering the global community is accusing us of. Hopefully, the steps they take will affect the real culprits and not hit the innocent, small businesses with the collateral damage of excessive regulation.

item.title: Ballot papers for Dei Open By Election delivered to Mt Hagen
item.description:
Ballot papers for the Dei Open seat by-election arrived in Mt Hagen on a PNG Air charter plane from Port Moresby to Mt Hagen yesterday and was brought into Kiminiga Police Barracks where it was later locked away with escort from Mt Hagen Police and Defence forces.

With 25 confirmed candidates contesting and well over 60, 000 plus eligible voters from poll to poll as per the LLG census count in 2024 the date is set for poll to begin on Monday 19th January 2026.

item.title: Monsoon troughs bring rain, strong winds, and storms to PNG
item.description:
A series of weather systems called monsoon troughs are affecting parts of Papua New Guinea and the Pacific region, bringing heavy rains and strong winds.

One of these troughs stretches from Australia’s Townsville across the Coral Sea and into areas near New Caledonia, Vanuatu, and Fiji.

item.title: Road opens lifeline for rural farmers cut off from markets and basic services
item.description:
For years, farmers in the interior of Usino LLG have struggled to move their cocoa, coffee and food crops to market because there was no proper road. That is now changing.

Construction has started on the 14-kilometre Negeri–Begesin–Manipur road, a long-awaited project that will serve more than 6,000 people in the Begesin–Girawa area of Usino Bundi.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: US files for warrants to seize dozens more Venezuela-linked oil tankers, sources say
item.description: LONDON — The U.S. government has filed for court ‌warrants to seize dozens more tankers linked to the Venezuelan oil trade, four sources familiar with the matter said, as Washington consolidates control of oil shipments in and out of the South American country. The U.S. military and Coast Guard have seized five vessels in recent weeks in international waters that were either carrying Venezuelan ‍oil or have done so in the past. The seizures were part of Washington’s campaign to force Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro out of power that culminated in U.S. forces capturing him on January 3.

item.description: WASHINGTON — The United States’ greenhouse gas emissions increased by 2.4% in 2025 after two years of decline amid a resurgence of coal power, according to estimates published Tuesday by the Rhodium Group, a research firm.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — The United States’ greenhouse gas emissions increased by 2.4% in 2025 after two years of decline amid a resurgence of coal power, according to estimates published Tuesday by the Rhodium Group, a research firm.

item.title: Jayson Sablan reflects on coastal change in ‘Ta Na’i Ånimu II: Sacred Waters’
item.description: By Ron Rocky Coloma On Saipan’s coastlines, change often arrives quietly. It shows up in familiar fishing spots, gathering places and shorelines that feel unchanged until they are not. That slow realization sits at the center of photographer Jayson Sablan’s work, now on view at the Guam Museum as part of an exhibition that blends art, memory and environmental concern. More than 35 artists from across the Mariana Islands are participating in “Ta Na’i Ånimu II: Sacred Waters,” which opened...

item.title: Tkatchenko reaffirmed diplomatic ties with China
item.description:
Foreign Affairs Minister Justin Tkatchenko has reaffirmed that Papua New Guinea will continue to strengthen its diplomatic relationship with China, its biggest economic and trade partners, on Friday, January 9th, 2026

In a meeting with Ambassador of the People's Republic of China, His Excellency Yang Xiaoguang, the first for the year, Minister Tkatchenko emphasized PNG's commitment to continue to work together to grow relations and opportunities that will benefit both the people, the produce and the business sector.

item.title: Marape flags cabinet re-alignment
item.description:
Prime Minister James Marape has announced that his government is entering a period of performance-based Cabinet realignment as Papua New Guinea moves into what he described as a decisive “year of reset” following the nation’s 50th Independence anniversary.

Speaking at Government House after the swearing-in of Kompiam-Ambum MP Sir John Pundari, Tewai-Siassi MP Dr Kobby Bomareo and Menyamya MP Solen Loifa as Ministers of State, Prime Minister Marape said the appointments were both a recognition of political balance in the coalition and a strategic move to strengthen government delivery in 2026.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Marape flags cabinet re-alignment appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/PM-3.png?w=800)
Prime Minister James Marape has announced that his government is entering a period of performance-based Cabinet realignment as Papua New Guinea moves into what he described as a decisive “year of reset” following the nation’s 50th Independence anniversary.
Speaking at Government House after the swearing-in of Kompiam-Ambum MP Sir John Pundari, Tewai-Siassi MP Dr Kobby Bomareo and Menyamya MP Solen Loifa as Ministers of State, Prime Minister Marape said the appointments were both a recognition of political balance in the coalition and a strategic move to strengthen government delivery in 2026.

item.title: PC Online Tidbits
item.description:
Visible from space. Goodness!
Our same Henao Drive road from above, we took screenshots of from Google Earth. Guess what. It can be viewed from space. We were right after all. The heavens will have to come down fix this bad road. To make matters worse there is one State Minister and another two MPs that live in the same area, that includes the current Opposition leader. As we said, there needs to be divine intervention here, as even the car dodging the potholes are clearly captured from space all over the place. We thought it was a three-lane road!

The post PC Online Tidbits appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Banks warn consumers will be hurt by Trump’s 10% cap on credit card interest rates
item.description: U.S. banks and financial institutions on Monday pushed back against President Donald Trump’s proposed cap on credit card interest rates, citing new data that showed it would result in millions of American households and small businesses losing access to credit. Trump, who is ‍under pressure to address voter concerns over the cost of living, on Friday called for a one-year cap on credit card interest rates at 10% starting on January 20. He did not provide details on how such a ban would be imposed, and some industry experts said it would require congressional action.
item.source:markdown: U.S. banks and financial institutions on Monday pushed back against President Donald Trump’s proposed cap on credit card interest rates, citing new data that showed it would result in millions of American households and small businesses losing access to credit. Trump, who is ‍under pressure to address voter concerns over the cost of living, on Friday called for a one-year cap on credit card interest rates at 10% starting on January 20. He did not provide details on how such a ban would be imposed, and some industry experts said it would require congressional action.

item.title: Obituaries for January 13
item.description: Jafra Lehua Kahealani Depontes, 43, of Kailua-Kona died Oct. 24. She was a loving daughter, wife and mother. Visitation 10:30-11:30 a.m. Sunday, Jan. 18 at Kahaluu Ma Kai. Celebration of life service at 11:30 a.m. Luncheon to follow. Survived by husband, Andrew; daughters, Kilihea, Anaha, One‘ula; father, Jayme (Sabine) Depontes; mother Liane Depontes; brother, Nainoa (Emily) Depontes; stepbrothers. Kane Depontes and Ryan Depontes; grandmother, Nita Depontes; aunts, uncles, a nephew and cousins. Arrangements by Nuuanu Memorial Park and Mortuary.

item.title: Lloyds Metals continues community support through new donation
item.description:
In a major boost for healthcare in Central Bougainville, Lloyds Metals and Energy Ltd (LMEL) has donated a critical consignment of medical supplies to Arawa District Hospital (ADH), addressing a chronic drug shortage that has plagued the facility for years.

The donation comes at a time when the Autonomous Region of Bougainville (AROB) health sector is facing significant logistical challenges. For many patients at Arawa Hospital, a lack of basic medicine has meant receiving prescriptions only to be forced to buy them at expensive private pharmacies, with some even traveling as far as Buka to find essential drugs.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Lloyds Metals continues community support through new donation appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/Dilip-Harischandra-Burade-2nd-from-right-presenting-the-medical-supplies-to-Arawa-Hospital-aCEO-Mr-Ignatius-Giranah-and-Gwen-Kolonga-ADH-Pharmacist-far-right.-.png?w=800)

item.title: Kokoda leaders reconcile to foster unity and progress
item.description:
In a significant move for political stability in Central Bougainville, former Member for Kokoda, Rodney Osioco, and the incumbent Member, Philip Pinaung, have officially reconciled.

The reconciliation ceremony took place on Sunday at their home village of Sirovai, effectively ending a period of tension that followed a misunderstanding between their respective supporters during the last Autonomous Bougainville Government (ABG) elections.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Kokoda leaders reconcile to foster unity and progress appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Lae gets 250 new rubbish drums as businesses and authority team up to clean streets
item.description:
Lae residents will soon see 250 new galvanized rubbish drums placed around the city, a joint initiative between Barlow Industries Limited and the Lae City Authority (LCA).

Each drum can hold at least 300 litres of waste. The aim is to make it easier for residents to dispose of rubbish responsibly and keep the city clean.

item.title: Rain and Flood warnings issued for regions across PNG
item.description:
With Cyclone Koji hitting North Queensland, causing heavy rain and flooding, the Papua New Guinea National Weather Service has also issued heavy rain and flood warnings for regions across the country.

item.title: Amata’s awareness PSA reminds U.S. Nationals not to vote in other jurisdictions
item.description:
Source: Congresswoman Uifa’atali Amata’s D.C. staff

Washington, D.C. — (January 9, 2026) Congresswoman Uifa’atali Amata is reminding U.S. nationals from American Samoa that under current U.S. and state laws they absolutely cannot vote in elections outside of American Samoa unless they personally become U.S. citizens before voting. 

“It’s incredibly important to not become confused over this: U.S. nationals cannot vote outside our elections in American Samoa. Even if the poll workers do not stop you from voting, and you have a state driver’s license, it’s still not allowed, and can lead to huge legal problems,” said Congresswoman Amata. “If you want to vote in the United States, you must become a citizen first, even if you’ve lived in a U.S. community for many years.”

“Until we are certain that we have widespread 100 percent awareness of this fact, it’s helpful to have a reminder to be sure the word is out, and protect friends and family from a legal nightmare. It’s very important to make sure your graduating high schoolers who are still U.S. nationals know this clearly when they turn 18 and potentially go away to jobs and college,” Aumua Amata continued. “For those choosing citizenship, I have a bill to help that process for U.S. nationals, but nationals risk prosecution by voting in any state that requires U.S. citizenship to be eligible to vote, unless state law were to expressly provide that U.S. nationals also may vote in that state’s elections.”

Amata has introduced the American Samoa Statutory Nationality and Citizenship Act (H.R. 6158) to help individual U.S. nationals more readily transfer into U.S. citizenship as a personal choice, while not affecting American Samoa’s current status, which for over 125 years has protected the family land and chiefly (matai) systems within the traditional fa’a Samoa (Samoan way). 

The bill protects both collective self-determination for American Samoa and the individual rights of U.S. nationals, by enabling elective United States citizenship for individuals, and she will be posting more information about the bill in the months ahead. 

“I am saddened by the voting case in Alaska, and I hope the wonderful people of Alaska, where I’ve visited many times, will be forgiving of this mistake by the local U.S. nationals in their community,” Amata concluded. “Rather, I hope that this can become an educational moment, that the Lord can ‘work together for good’ by preventing future problems through public awareness while restoring our people in Alaska with compassion.” 

 

 

Section: 
Local News
Tags: 
Congresswoman Uifa’atali Amata
item.source:markdown:
[![us national passport](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/field/image/national_passport_2.jpg?itok=lz7egqBt)](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_normal_image/public/field/image/national_passport_2.jpg?itok=F3N61JSd)

“It’s incredibly important to not become confused over this: U.S. nationals cannot vote outside our elections in American Samoa. Even if the poll workers do not stop you from voting, and you have a state driver’s license, it’s still not allowed, and can lead to huge legal problems,” said Congresswoman Amata. “If you want to vote in the United States, you must become a citizen first, even if you’ve lived in a U.S. community for many years.”
“Until we are certain that we have widespread 100 percent awareness of this fact, it’s helpful to have a reminder to be sure the word is out, and protect friends and family from a legal nightmare. It’s very important to make sure your graduating high schoolers who are still U.S. nationals know this clearly when they turn 18 and potentially go away to jobs and college,” Aumua Amata continued. “For those choosing citizenship, I have a bill to help that process for U.S. nationals, but nationals risk prosecution by voting in any state that requires U.S. citizenship to be eligible to vote, unless state law were to expressly provide that U.S. nationals also may vote in that state’s elections.”

item.title: Virtual event today as comment period for Deep Sea Mining in Am Samoa closes
item.description:
Source: Right to Democracy Press Release

Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA — As the federal government considers opening U.S. territorial waters to deep sea mining, Pacific Island communities and territorial governments are going on record to oppose the imposition of these activities, warning of irreversible harm to ocean ecosystems, cultural lifeways, and the democratic rights of island peoples.

Just hours before the comment period closes this week, Right to Democracy, in partnership with the America the Beautiful for All Coalition, will host a virtual panel examining the federal call to open the waters of the Marianas to deep sea mining and its implications for island communities, ocean ecosystems, and self-determination.

The panel will feature Andra Samoa, Maria Hernández, and Sheila Babauta, all of whom are Right to Democracy Environment & Democracy Fellows, and will be co-moderated by Neil Weare, Co-Director of Right to Democracy, and Angelo Villagomez, Ocean Co-Lead for the America the Beautiful for All Coalition.

Local and national civil society organizations will announce the results of their respective outreach efforts and successes in submitting petitions, letters, and comments to the federal register. 

Special guests include Lt. Governor Joshua Tenorio, Speaker Frank Blas, Jr., and others.

The Virtual Panel Will Take Place:

  •           Monday, January 12th at 5:00pm EST, 6:00pm AST, 11:00 am SST (American Samoa)
  •           Tuesday, January 13th at 8:00am ChST (Guam / Northern Mariana Islands)

 

 

Section: 
Local News
Tags: 
deep sea mining

[![deep sea mining ](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/field/image/mining_in_deep_sea_copy_8.jpg?itok=4Ej4aKb9)](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_normal_image/public/field/image/mining_in_deep_sea_copy_8.jpg?itok=1NFkHGwy)

The panel will feature Andra Samoa, Maria Hernández, and Sheila Babauta, all of whom are Right to Democracy Environment & Democracy Fellows, and will be co-moderated by Neil Weare, Co-Director of Right to Democracy, and Angelo Villagomez, Ocean Co-Lead for the America the Beautiful for All Coalition.

item.title: Teacher shortage crisis deepens in Bougainville
item.description:
Bougainville’s education system is facing a severe teacher shortage, with more than 860 positions unfilled across the region, as officials announced the 2026 academic calendar this week.

Caretaker Secretary for Education Stanley Vavero confirmed the staffing gaps in a public update, detailing vacancies across all levels: 562 in elementary schools, 252 in primary schools, 9 in high schools, 3 in secondary schools, and 40 in vocational schools.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Teacher shortage crisis deepens in Bougainville appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/shortage-of-over-800-teachers.png?w=800)
Bougainville’s education system is facing a severe teacher shortage, with more than 860 positions unfilled across the region, as officials announced the 2026 academic calendar this week.
Caretaker Secretary for Education Stanley Vavero confirmed the staffing gaps in a public update, detailing vacancies across all levels: 562 in elementary schools, 252 in primary schools, 9 in high schools, 3 in secondary schools, and 40 in vocational schools.

Nissan and Atolls are the most remote constituencies of the North Bougainville electorate in the Autonomous Region of Bougainville.

item.title: Obituaries for January 12
item.description: Randall Raynard Dudoit, 66, of Naalehu died Dec. 18 at home. Born in Honolulu, he was a carpenter, ranch hand and professional boxer. Services at a late date. Survived by wife, Pammy Dudoit; children, Randy Boy Alu, Pandalia (Mark Lazaar) Makuakane, Sabino “Bino” Makuakane and Keoni Kekoa (Erin Santos) Dudoit; mother, Rosita Esperago; siblings, Reuben Dudoit, Marcellus Dudoit Jr., Emma Dudoit Parham, Curtis Dudoit, Rosalind Dudoit Pegues, Manuel “Kalani” Dudoit, Sean Dudoit, Shane Dudoit, Landis Dudoit, Marroc Dudoit Kamai, Mannon Dudoit Kamai, Mandon Dudoit Kamai, Myndrene “Sachiko” Dudoit Kamai, Mahonn Dudoit Kamai and Mark Dudoit; seven grandchildren and five great-grandchildren; nieces, nephews, aunts, uncles and cousins. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.

item.title: Cuba defiant after Trump says island to receive no more Venezuelan oil or money
item.description: HAVANA/HOUSTON — President Donald Trump ‌on Sunday said no more Venezuelan oil or money will go to Cuba and suggested the Communist-run island should strike a deal with Washington, ramping up pressure on the long-time U.S. nemesis and provoking defiant words from the island’s leadership.

item.title: Chalamet beats DiCaprio at Hollywood’s Golden Globes
item.description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — ‌Timothee Chalamet triumphed in one of the most competitive categories at the Golden Globes on Sunday, taking the trophy for best male actor in a movie musical or comedy for his role as a professional table tennis player in “Marty Supreme.” Chalamet defeated Leonardo DiCaprio, George Clooney ‍and other big names at the red-carpet ceremony in Beverly Hills, California. “This category is stacked. I look up to all of you,” Chalamet said to his fellow nominees.

item.title: PM Marape calls on public servants to drive PNG’s Reset@50 through discipline, integrity and results
item.description:
Prime Minister James Marape has called on Papua New Guinea's public servants to take personal and institutional responsibility for driving the nation's Reset@50 agenda,warning that the country’s next 20 years will determine the future of generations to come.

Prime Minister James Marape address the 2026 Public Servants Dedication Service at the Sir John Guise Indoor Stadium, highlighting PNG has now stepped beyond its first 50 years of Independence and must enter a new era of discipline, delivery and national renewal.

item.title: Bulls power past Dons in pre-season opener
item.description:
Doncaster RLFC fell to a 12-30 defeat against Betfred Super League side Bradford Bulls at the Eco-Power Stadium in their sole warm-up fixture ahead of the 2026 Championship campaign.

Despite the "friendly" billing, the contest sparked to life early when Bradford’s Rowan Milnes was sin-pinned just seven minutes in for a high challenge. However, the man disadvantage didn't deter the visitors, who opened the scoring through Esan Marsters after a slick shift to the left flank.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: A Breezy Escape: 45 Minutes from Port Moresby to Gaire
item.description:
Sometimes all you need is a short drive away from the city to reset your mind, especially when you’re a local visitor based in Kiunga, Western Province, visiting Port Moresby.

On Friday, January 9, we took a roughly 45-minute drive out of the National Capital District, heading towards Gaire Village in Central Province for a relaxing getaway. It didn’t take long for the busy city atmosphere to fade behind us as the open road welcomed the promise of sea breeze and quiet moments.

item.description:

item.title: PNG Lewas arrive in Nepal ahead of ICC Women’s T20 Global Qualifiers
item.description:
The Papua New Guinea Lewas have safely arrived in Nepal, touching down yesterday, Sunday 12 January 2026, as preparations intensify for the ICC Women’s T20 World Cup Global Qualifier.

The tournament, which runs from 14 January to 1 February 2026, will be hosted at the TU Cricket Ground and Upper Hulpani Cricket Ground in Nepal, bringing together some of the world’s leading associate women’s teams as they compete for qualification to the ICC Women’s T20 World Cup England & Wales 2026.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post PNG Lewas arrive in Nepal ahead of ICC Women’s T20 Global Qualifiers appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: NICTA supports Public Service dedication program with 150 cartons of water
item.description:
With the National Public Service Dedication Program commencing this morning the National Information and Communications Technology Authority (NICTA) has donated 150 cartons of bottled water to the Department for Community Development and Religion in support of the Program.

On behalf of NICTA Acting Chief Executive Officer, Mr Lume Polume, the donation was delivered by Mr George Pondrelei and Ms Amanda Tito to Program Development Director, Mr George Kulisi, and Assistant Director for Religion, Mr Rex Hibuye last week.

item.title: Marape calls on public servants to work and not “waste time”
item.description:
Public servants have been called on to work and not “waste time” to unnecessary delays, holidays and inefficiencies.

Prime Minister James Marape made this call yesterday in a statement reminding public servants that today’s Public Service Opening and Dedication Service is not a ceremonial formality, but a critical moment to reset, refocus and recommit the entire machinery of government to the task of national development.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: Tens of thousands protest in Minneapolis over fatal ICE shooting
item.description: MINNEAPOLIS, Minn. — Tens of thousands of people marched through Minneapolis on Saturday to decry the fatal shooting of a woman ‌by a U.S. immigration agent, part of more than 1,000 rallies planned nationwide this weekend against the federal government’s deportation drive. The massive turnout in Minneapolis despite a whipping, cold wind underscores how the fatal shooting of 37-year-old Renee Good by an Immigration and Customs Enforce-ment officer on Wednesday has struck a chord, fueling protests in major cities and some towns. Minnesota’s Democratic leaders and the administration of President Donald Trump, a Republican, have offered starkly different accounts of the incident.
item.source:markdown: MINNEAPOLIS, Minn. — Tens of thousands of people marched through Minneapolis on Saturday to decry the fatal shooting of a woman ‌by a U.S. immigration agent, part of more than 1,000 rallies planned nationwide this weekend against the federal government’s deportation drive. The massive turnout in Minneapolis despite a whipping, cold wind underscores how the fatal shooting of 37-year-old Renee Good by an Immigration and Customs Enforce-ment officer on Wednesday has struck a chord, fueling protests in major cities and some towns. Minnesota’s Democratic leaders and the administration of President Donald Trump, a Republican, have offered starkly different accounts of the incident.

item.title: $100 billion to revive Venezuela’s energy industry? Oil executives are not so sure.
item.description: Exxon Mobil has a long history of drilling in challenging environments. The largest U.S. oil company will go almost anywhere to extract hydrocarbons if it can manage the risk and make the numbers work. Exxon pumps crude in the deep water off the coast of Guyana and has invested some $19 billion to produce natural gas on the island nation of Papua New Guinea.

item.title: Obituaries for January 11
item.description: John E. Ambagis, 92, of Keaau died Jan. 2 at home. Born in New Haven, Conn., he was a retired psychotherapist specializing in children, police officer, world traveler and U.S. Navy Korean War-era veteran. Private services. Survived by wife, Mabel; sons, Johnny (Victoria) Ambagis, Kevin Ambagis, Jimmy (Regina) Ambagis, Joe (Cherisse) Ambagis, Jeffery (Chrissy) Ambagis and Stephen (Hilary) Ambagis; 13 grandchildren and 10 great grandchildren. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.

item.description: Aseries of lava fountains building a cone perched on the crater rim … sounds like the ongoing eruption in Halema‘uma‘u at the summit of Kilauea, but this description could also fit the Kilauea Iki eruption in 1959. Let’s compare these two episodic lava fountaining eruptions.

item.title: Cyclone winds topple power poles across Port Moresby; restoration efforts continue
item.description:
PNG Power Limited (PPL) technical teams are working through the night as a powerful weather system continues to batter the National Capital District, causing extensive damage to the city’s electrical grid.

As of 7:30 pm tonight, several major feeders remain out of service or are only partially restored following a day of destructive winds and heavy rain, triggered by the effects of a cyclone off the coast of Australia.

item.title: Bougainville Solar Plant generates first SOE revenue, lighting up Buin
item.description:
In a significant step toward economic self-reliance, the Bougainville Power and Water Corporation Limited (BPWCL) has begun generating its own revenue, becoming one of the first State-Owned Enterprises (SOEs) under the Autonomous Bougainville Government (ABG) to achieve this status.

This milestone follows the December commissioning of a one-megawatt solar power plant in Buin, South Bougainville. The plant now provides reliable electricity to approximately 250 households, schools, businesses, and health facilities in the town and its surrounding communities.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

This milestone follows the December commissioning of a one-megawatt solar power plant in Buin, South Bougainville. The plant now provides reliable electricity to approximately 250 households, schools, businesses, and health facilities in the town and its surrounding communities.

item.description:

item.title: Navigating the past and present: How Marshall Islands weaves old traditions into the fabric of modern world
item.description: In the Marshall Islands, seafaring and weaving are two traditions that withstood the test of time, amid pressures from modernization, migration and climate change. item.title: Report: Runway wall caused all deaths in S. Korean plane crash
item.description: SEOUL, South Korea — Everyone on board a Jeju Air flight that crashed and killed 179 people just over a year ago would have survived if a concrete wall at the end of the runway had instead been built with materials that break apart easily, a previously undisclosed report to the South Korean government said.
item.source:markdown: SEOUL, South Korea — Everyone on board a Jeju Air flight that crashed and killed 179 people just over a year ago would have survived if a concrete wall at the end of the runway had instead been built with materials that break apart easily, a previously undisclosed report to the South Korean government said.

item.title: Plane crash scare at Kanabea Airstrip
item.description:
An SDA Aviation aircraft narrowly avoided a crash early this morning at the Kanabea Airstrip in Kotindanga Local Level Government (LLG), Gulf Province, raising fresh concerns over aviation safety in remote parts of the country.

The incident occurred at approximately 8:20 am as the aircraft was attempting to land while transporting the body of a senior nursing officer. Several family members escorting the remains were also on board.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: Police condemn alleged compensation demands after Aumea Bridge collapse
item.description:
Business operations, including those of Ramu NiCo, have been disrupted following the collapse of the Aumea Bridge, which has severed a key section of the Madang–Lae–Highlands Highway.

Authorities are currently constructing a temporary wet crossing to allow traffic to resume while arrangements are made for the bridge to be rebuilt. The interim crossing is expected to restore access for commuters, freight operators, and businesses affected by the disruption.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: From Lae to Australia: How the PALM Scheme is changing lives
item.description:
When Markwin Awae boarded a flight from Lae to Australia three years ago, he carried more than just a suitcase. He carried the hopes of his family, the expectations of his community, and a fierce determination to build a better future.

Awae, who was born and raised in Lae City and hails from the Kabwum District of Morobe Province, is one of 91 workers deployed to Australia through the Lae Labour Mobility Unit under the Pacific Australia Labour Mobility (PALM) Scheme.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post From Lae to Australia: How the PALM Scheme is changing lives appeared first on Post Courier.
