item.title: Bishop warns against sea travel as strong wind alert hits Siassi waters
item.description:
ELCPNG Head Bishop Dr Jack Urame has warned delegates and the public against travelling by small boats to Siassi ahead of the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Papua New Guinea’s 2026 National Synod, citing serious safety concerns.

“This is a very challenging Synod because of the sea crossing,” Bishop Urame said. “We do not want to risk lives, and the church will not take responsibility if people travel in unsafe ways.”

The post Bishop warns against sea travel as strong wind alert hits Siassi waters appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Obituaries for January 9
item.description: Pilar Lucena De Mattos, 94, of Hilo died Dec. 26 at home. Born in Hawaii, she was a retired teacher at Laupahoehoe, Paauilo and Ookala schools. Private services. Survived by sons, Vernon De Mattos of Keaau, Marvin (Terry) De Mattos of Seattle and Shannon De Mattos of Las Vegas; daughter, Laura (Garrett) Balberde of Hilo; hanai sister, Edith Esteban of Hilo; brother-in-law, Juan Macanas of Pepeekeo; 10 grandchildren and 24 great-grandchildren; nieces and nephews. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.

item.title: US Senate votes to curb military action in Venezuela, Trump says oversight could last years
item.description: WASHINGTON — The U.S. Senate voted on Thursday to advance ‌a resolution that would bar President Donald Trump from taking further military action against Venezuela without congressional authorization, even as Trump said U.S. oversight of the troubled nation could last years.

item.title: Trump lays out a vision of power restrained only by ‘my own morality’
item.description: WASHINGTON — President Donald Trump declared Wednesday evening that his power as commander in chief is constrained only by his “own morality,” brushing aside international law and other checks on his ability to use military might to strike, invade or coerce nations around the world.

item.title: Puma Energy says there is no petrol shortage at its pumps
item.description:
PUMA Energy PNG Limited is not experiencing petrol shortages but that its experience was of high demand in recent days, according to Head of Commercial Peter Blatch.

This follows grievances of petrol shortages today (morning hours) in Port Moresby, as vehicles and taxi services flocked to fuel service stations across the city for petrol.

item.title: NPL delivers first Tax Credit Scheme project with restoration of staff housing at Paiam Hospital
item.description:
New Porgera Limited (NPL) has successfully completed maintenance works on three staff houses, marking the first project delivered under the Infrastructure Tax Credit Scheme (TCS) since the restart of the New Porgera operation. The Paiam Hospital is the district hospital for the Porgera-Paiela District.

Funded through the TCS at a total cost of over K185,000, the maintenance works commenced in November 2025 and were completed on 31 December 2025.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post NPL delivers first Tax Credit Scheme project with restoration of staff housing at Paiam Hospital appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/The-British-High-Commissioner-H.E.-Anne-Macro-with-the-Kings-Baton-1-1.png?w=800)
New Porgera Limited (NPL) has successfully completed maintenance works on three staff houses, marking the first project delivered under the Infrastructure Tax Credit Scheme (TCS) since the restart of the New Porgera operation. The Paiam Hospital is the district hospital for the Porgera-Paiela District.
Funded through the TCS at a total cost of over K185,000, the maintenance works commenced in November 2025 and were completed on 31 December 2025.

item.title: Australia supports PNG to drive improvement in health systems
item.description:
The Australasian College of Health Service Management (ACHSM) and the PNG National Department of Health have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to drive improvement in healthcare systems in PNG.

The MOU signed at the annual Asia-Pacific Health Leadership Congress in Darwin establishes a collaborative partnership aimed at strengthening health leadership capacity across PNG. This will support Papua New Guinean health leaders to engage with regional and international peers, and progress the establishment of an official PNG branch of ACHSM.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Australia supports PNG to drive improvement in health systems appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/feature-picture-24.png?w=800)
The Australasian College of Health Service Management (ACHSM) and the PNG National Department of Health have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to drive improvement in healthcare systems in PNG.
The MOU signed at the annual Asia-Pacific Health Leadership Congress in Darwin establishes a collaborative partnership aimed at strengthening health leadership capacity across PNG. This will support Papua New Guinean health leaders to engage with regional and international peers, and progress the establishment of an official PNG branch of ACHSM.

item.title: National Weather Service issue Gale warning for Southern Region
item.description:
THE Southern Region is expected to experience gale winds and rainfall up until late Saturday or early Sunday, said the PNG National Weather Service Assistant Director of Forecasting and Warning Benjamin Malai.

Mr Malai told the Post-Courier that the Southern Region, especially Western Province, Central, Gulf and Milne Bay are experiencing about 35 to 48 knots regarded as strong gale.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: King’s Baton arrives in Papua New Guinea to spark 2026 Commonwealth Games spirit
item.description:
The King’s Baton officially arrived in Papua New Guinea on Thursday, 8 January, marking a significant milestone in the 500-day global relay leading to the Glasgow 2026 Commonwealth Games.

 Originally sent forth by His Majesty The King from Buckingham Palace in March 2025, the Baton represents a tradition that connects and excites communities across the Commonwealth. This leg of the journey highlights the power of sport to inspire youth and strengthen international ties through inclusion and respect.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post King’s Baton arrives in Papua New Guinea to spark 2026 Commonwealth Games spirit appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/Former-PNG-Barramundis-players-proudly-carry-the-Kings-Baton-through-Hanuabada-as-part-of-the-Glasgow-2026-Commonwealth-Games-Relay.-1.jpg?w=800)
The King’s Baton officially arrived in Papua New Guinea on Thursday, 8 January, marking a significant milestone in the 500-day global relay leading to the Glasgow 2026 Commonwealth Games.

item.title: A landmark road development project launched to transform Poroma, Nipa and Kutubu corridor
item.description:
Prime Minister James Marape has officially launched the long-awaited Poroma-Kutubu road sealing project, marking a historic turning point for a region that has served as Papua New Guinea’s economic engine for over three decades.

The K371.5 million project, part of the Connect PNG infrastructure program, aims to seal over 100 kilometers of highway, finally linking the remote oil-producing heartland to the rest of the nation with high-quality infrastructure.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post A landmark road development project launched to transform Poroma, Nipa and Kutubu corridor appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: PNG Lewas register convincing win at Australian Country Championships
item.description:
The PNG Lewas continued their strong showing at the Toyota Australian Country Cricket Championships (Female Division) with a commanding 40-run victory over South Australia Country Women in a T20 match at Barossa Park, Lyndoch.

After winning the toss and electing to bat, the Lewas posted a competitive total of 133 for 7 from their allotted 20 overs. The batting effort was backed by a disciplined bowling display, with PNG restricting South Australia to 93 for 7 in 20 overs to seal a comfortable win.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post PNG Lewas register convincing win at Australian Country Championships appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Local leaders welcome King’s Baton to Hanuabada
item.description:
The 2026 Commonwealth Games King’s Baton Relay was met with a vibrant celebration today as it arrived in the historic stilt village of Hanuabada, the ancestral home of the Motu-Koitabu people.

National Capital District (NCD) Governor Powes Parkop was on hand to receive the Baton, marking a key milestone in the Port Moresby leg of the relay. The ceremony highlighted the village's unique sporting heritage, with the Baton at one point travelling by water to navigate the sprawling overwater.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Local leaders welcome King’s Baton to Hanuabada appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Obituaries for January 8
item.description: George Yuzuru Ikeda, 77, of Pahoa died Oct. 17 at Legacy Hilo Rehabilitation and Nursing Center. Born in Japan, he was a retired county Parks and Recreation district supervisor. Private services held. No flowers or koden (monetary gifts). Online condolences: dodomortuary.com. Survived by wife, Mae Ikeda of Pahoa; son, Reid (Anela) Ikeda of Hilo; brothers-in-law, Ronald Nakamoto of Hilo, Ray Nakamoto of Waimea and Alan (Joni) Nakamoto of Waikoloa; sisters-in-law, Ilona (Mark) Haggerty of Waimea, Doreen Nakamoto and Viola Alfson of California, Joyce Ikeda of Hilo; nephews and nieces. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.
item.source:markdown: George Yuzuru Ikeda, 77, of Pahoa died Oct. 17 at Legacy Hilo Rehabilitation and Nursing Center. Born in Japan, he was a retired county Parks and Recreation district supervisor. item.title: Jiwaka Township will experience power outage for maintenance work
item.description:
The township of Jiwaka in the Ramu Grid will experience an emergency power outage on Friday, January 9, 2026, from 9:00 am to 4:00 pm for maintenance work.

This power outage is due to maintenance work on a faulty tap on Kudjip's 66kV/22kV Transformer, which has been causing low voltage in the township area.

item.title: Continuous rain in Aitape demands prompt response from the Aitape-Lumi DDAC and West Sepik Disaster office
item.description:
Aitape Central LLG's ward 11 councilor Mr Benedict Moskem, is calling on the Aitape-Lumi District Development Authority and the West Sepik Provincial Disaster office for an immediate response to address excess flooding in his ward following the continuous rain in Aitape since last week.

The continuous rain has flooded most of the low-lying areas of ward 11, covering food gardens, overflowing toilet pits, and water wells, and it is a serious concern regarding the daily lives of people.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: Governor Powes welcomes Post- Courier’s bold stand against gender based violence
item.description:
National Capital District (NCD) Governor and Chairman of the Parliamentary Committee on Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment, Powes Parkop, has formally welcomed the Post-Courier’s decision to launch a weekly publication dedicated to the fight against gender-based violence (GBV).

The campaign, which will focus on promoting gender equality and women’s empowerment, is being hailed as a critical step in addressing one of Papua New Guinea's most deep-seated social crises.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Governor Powes welcomes Post- Courier’s bold stand against gender based violence appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Letter to the Editor: Disciplined execution consistent with the One Guam framework
item.description: By Rory Respicio As the Port of Guam enters 2026, the focus is on continuity through execution. This will not be a year of reset or redirection. It will be a year centered on delivering commitments already made, protecting the systems built over time and ensuring the port continues to perform reliably as modernization advances. This message is a clear case for continuity of management and leadership principles under shared governance. The progress outlined here did not occur in isolation, by...

item.title: Governor General officially launches 2026 Commonwealth Games King’s Baton Relay in PNG
item.description:
PORT MORESBY – Governor General Sir Bob Dadai has officially launched the Papua New Guinea leg of the 2026 Commonwealth Games King’s Baton Relay, marking the start of a journey intended to inspire unity and national pride across the country.

During a formal ceremony at Government House, Sir Bob Dadai praised the collaborative effort required to host the historic event, extending his gratitude to government and diplomatic partners, sponsors, volunteers, and community leaders.

item.title: Ipatas Cup finals to ignite Lae city
item.description:
THE 20th edition of the National Gaming Control Board Ipatas Cup for the eight mainland provinces of Papua New Guinea has set the stage for each Gold Pass winner to face off in the elimination and grand final at the Lae Rugby League oval this weekend.

Tomorrow, will see the champions from the Eastern Highlands (Lisapeka Bulldogs) play the Simbu champions (Jaka Elimbari Miners), the Morobe champions (Morobe Pride) against the Western Highlands champions (Young Stars), then the Hela champions (Tari Central) against the reigning champions representing the Jiwaka Province (Kulaka West) and the main game between the Enga champs (Prum Panthers) and the Southern Highlands champs (Pepka Hawks).

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Ipatas Cup finals to ignite Lae city appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Collapsed bridges disrupt business flow along Madang highway
item.description:
The collapse of two bridges along the Sir Bruce Jeffcott Highway has disrupted the flow of business to and from Lae and the Highlands to Madang Province.

The surging impacts of the Omiya and Yanamu rivers, respectively, caused by heavy downpours on Monday night, led to the collapse of the bridges named Omiya and Yanamu on Tuesday at 3 a.m., January 7, 2026.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Collapsed bridges disrupt business flow along Madang highway appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: NARI, JICA partner to roll out SHEP Farming Project in East New Britain
item.description:
The National Agricultural Research Institute (NARI), in partnership with the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) and the East New Britain Provincial Government, has announced the implementation of the Project for Capacity Development of Sustainable Integrated Farming System using the SHEP Approach in East New Britain Province.

The project, which will be coordinated from NARI Keravat, will be rolled out across all four districts of the province. SHEP, or Smallholder Horticulture Empowerment Project, is designed to transform smallholder farming by shifting practices from the traditional “grow and sell” approach to a more market-oriented “grow to sell” strategy.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post NARI, JICA partner to roll out SHEP Farming Project in East New Britain appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Chris the walkabout salesman
item.description:
Christopher Molas Jnr is an entrepreneur with a knack for door-to-door sales. He makes up to K700-K800 selling everyday household items as a "travelling salesman" on the streets of Buka, Arawa, Buin and other locations in Bougainville.

Chris hails from Lemankoa, Haku Constituency and Wakunai in the Rau Constituency of Central Bougainville. He started his "liklik bisnis" in 2018 and fondly recalls being drawn into entrepreneurship by friends and relatives who were actively involved in the informal sector.

item.title: AROB mourns the passing Bougainville Boundaries Commissioner
item.description:
Bougainville is mourning the loss of a vibrant and charismatic civil servant and patriot, the Late John Sisiesi - Acting Commissioner of the Bougainville Boundaries Commission. 

News of his death has been met by profound sadness by all who knew him; as it was formally announced to the public today in Buka by family representatives Andrew Sisiesi and Chris Siriosi who confirmed his untimely passing in the early hours of Tuesday morning, at his family home.

item.description: The trial of one ​of the first police officers on the ‌scene of the 2022 attack at a Texas elementary school that killed 19 students and two teachers opened ‌on Tuesday, with prosecutors accusing him of criminally failing to try to stop the slaughter, while the defense said the officer did the best he could at the chaotic and confusing scene.

item.title: Zelenskyy’s assessment darkens as Europeans gather to talk peace
item.description: KYIV, Ukraine — As Ukraine peace talks have stretched on for nearly a year, through fits and spurts and dozens of rounds, President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has accentuated the positive. The talks are now “90% complete,” he said. Ukraine works every minute to end the war, he insisted.
item.source:markdown: KYIV, Ukraine — As Ukraine peace talks have stretched on for nearly a year, through fits and spurts and dozens of rounds, President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has accentuated the positive. The talks are now “90% complete,” he said. Ukraine works every minute to end the war, he insisted.

item.title: Venezuela under Maduro shipped gold worth $5.2 billion to Switzerland
item.description: ZURICH — Venezuela transported gold worth almost 4.14 billion Swiss francs ($5.20 billion) ​to Switzerland during the ‌early years of the leadership of ousted President Nicolas ‌Maduro, customs data shows.
item.source:markdown: ZURICH — Venezuela transported gold worth almost 4.14 billion Swiss francs ($5.20 billion) ​to Switzerland during the ‌early years of the leadership of ousted President Nicolas ‌Maduro, customs data shows.

item.title: Maduro opponent Machado vows to return to Venezuela, wants an election
item.description: WASHINGTON — Venezuela’s main opposition leader, Maria Corina Machado, has vowed to return home quickly, praising U.S. President Donald Trump for toppling ‌her enemy Nicolas Maduro and declaring her movement ready to win a free election. Trump appears, however, to hope for now to work with interim President Delcy Rodriguez and other senior officials from Maduro’s government, disappointing the opposition and contributing to nervousness in Venezuela. Venezuelan and U.S. officials are discussing the export of Venezuelan crude to U.S. refiners, five government, industry and shipping sources told Reuters. “I’m planning to go back to Venezuela as soon as possible,” said Machado, 58, who escaped from Venezuela in disguise in October to receive the Nobel Peace Prize, which she dedicated to Trump.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — Venezuela’s main opposition leader, Maria Corina Machado, has vowed to return home quickly, praising U.S. President Donald Trump for toppling ‌her enemy Nicolas Maduro and declaring her movement ready to win a free election. Trump appears, however, to hope for now to work with interim President Delcy Rodriguez and other senior officials from Maduro’s government, disappointing the opposition and contributing to nervousness in Venezuela. Venezuelan and U.S. officials are discussing the export of Venezuelan crude to U.S. refiners, five government, industry and shipping sources told Reuters. “I’m planning to go back to Venezuela as soon as possible,” said Machado, 58, who escaped from Venezuela in disguise in October to receive the Nobel Peace Prize, which she dedicated to Trump.

item.title: Stray bullet hits PNG Power headquarters in Port Moresby
item.description:
PNG Power Limited (PPL) has confirmed that a bullet struck the glass frontage of its headquarters building in Port Moresby on Tuesday night, 6 January 2026, in an incident that occurred after business hours.

According to the company, the incident took place at approximately 10:00pm at the PNG Power Ltd Head Office, specifically near the Properties Office area. No staff were present at the time and no injuries were reported.

item.title: North Bougainville MP Francesca Semoso delivers K1 million worth of medical equipment and infrastructure to Buka General Hospital
item.description:
North Bougainville MP and Assistant Speaker of the National Parliament, Francesca Rianna Semoso, has handed over a range of essential medical equipment, vehicles, and infrastructure improvements valued at part of a K2 million commitment to Buka General Hospital, emphasising her ongoing support for strengthening healthcare services in the region.

In a ceremony witnessed by key health officials and community leaders, Ms Francesca Semoso presented the items on behalf of her K2 million funding allocation presented earlier on 16 May 2025. The handover was received by the Minister for Health and North Bougainville Women's Representative, Delourdes Semoso, alongside Buka General Hospital CEO Dr. Tommy Wotsia. Also present were Acting Health Secretary Mr. Matthew Monei, Tsitalato Constituency Member, Mr John Bosco Ragu, Buka Town Manager, Mr. Fidelis Semoso, chairpersons of the Community Government, and members of the general public.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post North Bougainville MP Francesca Semoso delivers K1 million worth of medical equipment and infrastructure to Buka General Hospital appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/feature-picture-8.png?w=800)

In a ceremony witnessed by key health officials and community leaders, Ms Francesca Semoso presented the items on behalf of her K2 million funding allocation presented earlier on 16 May 2025. The handover was received by the Minister for Health and North Bougainville Women's Representative, Delourdes Semoso, alongside Buka General Hospital CEO Dr. Tommy Wotsia. Also present were Acting Health Secretary Mr. Matthew Monei, Tsitalato Constituency Member, Mr John Bosco Ragu, Buka Town Manager, Mr. Fidelis Semoso, chairpersons of the Community Government, and members of the general public.

item.title: In memoriam: Alumna, educator Nālani Kanakaʻole
item.description:
UH Hilo alumna Faith Nālani Kanakaʻole, a revered kumu hula and cultural leader, shaped Hawaiian cultural practice and Indigenous education.

The post In memoriam: Alumna, educator Nālani Kanakaʻole first appeared on University of Hawaiʻi System News.

item.title: PNG Correctional Services officers complete NSW study tour
item.description:
A team of senior officers from Papua New Guinea Correctional Services (PNGCS), led by Acting Commissioner Bernard Nepo, has completed a week-long study tour in New South Wales, Australia, aimed at strengthening correctional services in Papua New Guinea.

The study tour was supported by the Australia–PNG Law and Justice Partnership and hosted by Corrective Services NSW (CSNSW). During the visit, officers were exposed to a range of correctional operations, including custodial management, rehabilitation programmes, community-based corrections, specialised security protocols, and prison industries.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post PNG Correctional Services officers complete NSW study tour appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/PNG-CS.png?w=800)

item.title: What lies beneath: The wealth beneath the Marianas waves
item.description: Seamount crusts/Photo courtesy of NOAA According to the U.S. Geological Survey, the following minerals are likely present in the CNMI waters: Cobalt-rich iron-manganese crusts occur on the sea­mounts located east of the Mariana Trench. Data for crusts from nearby seamounts indicate that crusts on sea­mounts within that sector of the CNMI EEZ have an excel­lent potential to be thick and have high contents of cobalt, nickel, and platinum. It is recommended that these sea­mounts be explored...
item.source:markdown: Seamount crusts/Photo courtesy of NOAA According to the U.S. Geological Survey, the following minerals are likely present in the CNMI waters: Cobalt-rich iron-manganese crusts occur on the sea­mounts located east of the Mariana Trench. Data for crusts from nearby seamounts indicate that crusts on sea­mounts within that sector of the CNMI EEZ have an excel­lent potential to be thick and have high contents of cobalt, nickel, and platinum. It is recommended that these sea­mounts be explored...

item.title: Obituaries for January 6
item.description: Byron Keali‘ihelepo Ayoso 71, of Hilo died Nov. 21 at Hilo Benioff Medical Center. Born in Kohala, he was a U.S. Air Force retiree. Visitation 10-11 a.m. Monday, Jan. 26 2026, at The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 55-524 Hawi Rd. in Hawi. Military honors 11:30 a.m-noon with burial to follow Wednesday, Jan. 28, at East Hawaii Veterans Cemetery No. 2 in Hilo. Online condolences: homelanimemorialpark.com. Survived by wife, Amanda Ayoso of Hilo; six children; 14 grandchildren; other family. Arrangements by Homelani Memorial Park.

item.title: Pentagon to cut Senator Kelly’s military retirement pay, alleging ‘reckless misconduct’
item.description: WASHINGTON — President Donald Trump’s Pentagon ‌chief announced plans on Monday to demote U.S. Senator Mark Kelly from his rank as a retired Navy captain for alleged “reckless misconduct” after he and other Democratic lawmakers urged troops to refuse any illegal orders.

item.title: Gov. Tim Walz drops reelection bid, and Amy Klobuchar may run instead
item.description: ST. PAUL, Minn. — Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota said Monday that he was abandoning his bid for reelection to a third term. And Sen. Amy Klobuchar, a fellow Democrat, is considering seeking the office, two people briefed on conversations between the two politicians said.

item.title: Betelnut chewing and smoking ban enforced in Madang CBD
item.description:
The restriction on betelnut chewing and smoking in public places in the Madang Central Business District is a national law and not a policy of the Madang Urban Local Level Government.

Madang Governor and Provincial Member Ramsey Pariwa clarified this following recent arrests in Madang town after enforcement began on Thursday, January 1, 2026. Governor Pariwa said the law was enacted by Parliament and carries the same legal weight and penalties as other national laws.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Betelnut chewing and smoking ban enforced in Madang CBD appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: PM Marape: Fisheries can anchor PNG’s economic independence as Daru Command Centre is commissioned
item.description:
Prime Minister, James Marape, declares that the fisheries sector has the potential to anchor up to half of Papua New Guineas economy as he authorized the National Fisheries Authority Monitoring, Control and Surveillance (MCS) command center in Daru.

At the peak of the occasion, Marape described the fisheries sector as a strategic pillar in PNG’s journey towards full economic independence, as he addressed national and provincial leaders, development partners and local communities.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post PM Marape: Fisheries can anchor PNG’s economic independence as Daru Command Centre is commissioned appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Police urge formal complaint over alleged assault case
item.description:
Madang Provincial Police Commander Superintendent Robert Baim has urged the public to formally report alleged cases of police brutality instead of relying only on Facebook posts.

His comments follow a social media post titled “Enough is enough: Police brutality must stop”, which alleges that a uniformed police officer assaulted a local man in his 50s on 2 January 2026 near a supermarket in the Ramu area.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Police urge formal complaint over alleged assault case appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: PM Marape launches National Fisheries Surveillance Command Centre to protect PNG’s sovereignty and marine wealth
item.description:
Prime Minister James Marape has officially opened a new fisheries surveillance centre in Daru, Western Province, marking a major step in protecting Papua New Guinea's marine resources and sovereignty.

The launching of the National Fisheries Authority's (NFA) Monitoring, Control and Surveillance (MCS) Command Centre in Daru is a major milestone aimed at safeguarding the country's marine resources, sovereignty and future economic security.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post PM Marape launches National Fisheries Surveillance Command Centre to protect PNG’s sovereignty and marine wealth appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Teachers to resume duties ahead of Students in 2026
item.description:
The Department of Education has announced that teachers will resume their duties earlier than students to prepare for the upcoming academic year.

In a circular released by the department , teachers across the country are advised that they will officially resume duties on Monday, January 19, 2026. Students are scheduled to begin classes one week later, on Monday, January 26, 2026.

item.title: PM commends communities and security forces for peaceful festive season
item.description:
Prime Minister James Marape has commended Papua New Guineans across the country for maintaining relative peace and order during the 2025 Christmas and New Year festive period, describing the overall national conduct as “better than most years” and an encouraging start to the nation’s next 50 years.

The Prime Minister said reports received at the start of the working year indicated that, aside from a small number of alcohol-fuelled incidents and isolated New Year disturbances, the festive season had been largely calm across all provinces, including the Autonomous Region of Bougainville.

item.title: Cash-trapping scam discovered on local bank ATM
item.description:
By 
Samoa News staff
reporters@samoanews.com

Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA — Customers of the Territorial Bank of American Samoa (TBAS) have been actively voicing their concerns on social media about a troubling cash-trapping scheme reported at the bank's Automated Teller Machine (ATM) located within the Laufou Shopping Center in Nuʻuuli. 

Several social media accounts have surfaced, detailing allegations that certain individuals have strategically applied tape to the ATM’s cash dispenser. This disturbing tactic is designed to misappropriate customer withdrawals. One account described a troubling incident in which a customer attempted to withdraw funds from an ATM. Although he received a receipt indicating that the transaction was successful, he was shocked to find that no physical cash was dispensed. Upon closer inspection of the cash dispenser, he discovered tape blocking the exit, with the cash he had attempted to withdraw stuck to it.

This alarming incident has since been reported to TBAS management. Cash-trapping scams have become a troubling trend, reported in communities across the United States and internationally. These schemes typically involve placing a device or obstruction over the cash dispenser slot to prevent the release of funds. In these scenarios, the customer’s account is debited, yet no cash is dispensed. Victims often assume the ATM is malfunctioning and leave, allowing the perpetrator to return, remove the obstruction, and claim the trapped cash.

In response to these concerns, TBAS President and Chief Executive Officer Owen Perry addressed local media, confirming the bank's awareness of the troubling reports. He indicated that TBAS is actively investigating the situation, which appears to be limited to this ATM location for now. “Upon learning about the issue, the bank quickly contacted the Department of Public Safety and is cooperating fully while conducting an internal review,” Perry stated.

Perry further emphasized, “Our ATMs undergo regular monitoring and inspections, and we are continually evaluating and enhancing our security protocols across all locations.” TBAS strongly encourages any customer who experiences difficulties at a TBAS ATM or notices any anomalies to contact the bank immediately, enabling a swift response and resolution.

Due to the ongoing investigation, Perry noted that the bank cannot share specific details about the incidents at this time. “Our top priority is to ensure the safety of our customers while maintaining the integrity of our banking services,” he remarked.

 

 

Section: 
Local News
Tags: 
cash trapping scam
item.source:markdown:
[![CASH TRAPPING ](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/field/image/cash_trapping_examples.jpg?itok=A10eMQF3)](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_normal_image/public/field/image/cash_trapping_examples.jpg?itok=uHKEcqoy)

item.title: Letter to the Editor: The ocean is not just a resource; it embodies cultural heritage
item.description: J Across Guam and the wider Western Pacific, the ocean is more than geography; it is livelihood, culture, and legacy. For island communities whose histories, economies and identities are inseparable from the sea, decisions made far from our shores carry lasting consequences. item.title: Mother of three boys welcomes long-awaited daughter
item.description:
For 34-year-old Jenelyn Pasangu, New Year’s Day 2026 brought a long-awaited miracle: a healthy baby girl.

item.title: Solar-powered water upgrade for Yanga Village
item.description:
Residents of Yanga Village near Lae can now enjoy improved access to clean and reliable water after Ahi Investment Limited funded the repair and upgrade of the community’s bore water system.

The project, delivered through the Ahi Charitable Trust, restored a damaged water tank and upgraded the system using solar-powered technology. The bore water system was originally donated by the Lae City Authority, but one of its tanks was damaged and became non-functional, affecting water supply for the village.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Solar-powered water upgrade for Yanga Village appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: New Ambulance for Lato Constituency
item.description:
Lato Constituency in South Bougainville is making significant progress in efforts to boost ambulatory emergency care and rural healthcare, as seen with the unveiling of a brand new ambulance by Minister for Community Development and Member for Lato Constituency, Melvin Wilolopa.

Minister Wilolopa announced the timely "New Year's gift" to constituents, stating that his people would no longer be denied access to essential transportation for urgent medical care.

item.title: Letter to the Editor: Your vote carries more weight than you know
item.description: While we are just a few days into the new year, we are well into the 2026 Guam election cycle. Many different organizations will be pushing hard to get folks to the polls and cast their vote for those candidates who they believe best represent today’s issues and those of the foreseeable future. Whether these organizations are faith-based, service-oriented, business, philanthropic or political, the arguments will be made for and against candidates all who can best take care of those issues...

item.title: Two foreigners on the run after allegedly stealing money
item.description:
TWO Bangladeshi man are on the run after they allegedly stole money and company documents from their employer.

Owner and managing director of Al-Rafi Trading Limited in Goroka, Eastern Highlands Province, Siful Mondol reported that the two committed the offence on December 20, 2025 in Lae, Morobe province, while he was away in Bangladesh visiting his family.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Two foreigners on the run after allegedly stealing money appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/TOP-1.png?w=800)
TWO Bangladeshi man are on the run after they allegedly stole money and company documents from their employer.
Owner and managing director of Al-Rafi Trading Limited in Goroka, Eastern Highlands Province, Siful Mondol reported that the two committed the offence on December 20, 2025 in Lae, Morobe province, while he was away in Bangladesh visiting his family.

item.title: New Guinea’s forests
item.description:
New Guinea is staggeringly rich in life. Occupying just 0.5% of Earth’s land surface, it hosts an estimated 5-8% of all species. This abundance is reflected in more than 2,800 orchid species, over 1,000 butterflies and around 800 birds. Over half of its known species are found nowhere else on Earth.

The post New Guinea’s forests appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Kerema to host Papua LNG Forum despite landowner objections
item.description:
Kerema Town has been confirmed as the host venue for the upcoming Papua LNG Development Forum, despite calls from some landowners for the meeting to be relocated to Port Moresby over safety and health concerns.

Member for Kerema and Minister for Finance Thomas Opa has assured all stakeholders that comprehensive planning and resourcing are already in place to ensure the successful hosting of the nationally significant forum.

item.title: Democrats raise alarms after Trump avoids congressional approval for Maduro’s capture
item.description: WASHINGTON — Republicans in Congress on Saturday cheered the Trump administration’s dramatic military action to capture President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela, but top Democrats sounded alarms about the legality of the operation and said they would seek a quick vote to halt hostilities without express authorization.

item.title: Managers of Swiss bar are suspected of negligence in deadly fire, police say
item.description: CRANS-MONTANA, Switzerland — The two managers of a bar in the Swiss Alps where at least 40 people died in a sudden fire early New Year’s Day have been placed under criminal investigation because of allegations of negligence, police said Saturday, as authorities in Switzerland come under growing pressure to explain whether flaws in the site’s design and management fueled the disaster.
item.source:markdown: CRANS-MONTANA, Switzerland — The two managers of a bar in the Swiss Alps where at least 40 people died in a sudden fire early New Year’s Day have been placed under criminal investigation because of allegations of negligence, police said Saturday, as authorities in Switzerland come under growing pressure to explain whether flaws in the site’s design and management fueled the disaster.

item.title: Obituaries for January 4
item.description: Marciana Ogoc Estencion, 77, of Kailua-Kona died, Dec. 4 at Kona Community Hospital. Born in Kealakekua, she was a stock clerk for the former KMart and delivered newspapers for West Hawaii Today. Visitation 8:30-10 a.m. Friday, Jan. 23, at St. John’s Catholic Church in Kealakekua. Mass at 10 a.m. Burial to follow at Kona Memorial Park in Holualoa. Casual attire. Survived by son, James Mark (Roslyn) Thomas of Kona; stepchildren, Yolanda (Rick) Bautista of Honolulu, Alfred Estencion of Kona, Darren Estencion of Maui and Eldaine Barawis of Kailua-Kona; godchildren, Casey Keohuloa, Pikake Keohuloa and Trina Kauhaihao; three grandchildren; nieces, nephews, and cousins. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.
item.source:markdown: Marciana Ogoc Estencion, 77, of Kailua-Kona died, Dec. 4 at Kona Community Hospital. Born in Kealakekua, she was a stock clerk for the former KMart and delivered newspapers for West Hawaii Today. Visitation 8:30-10 a.m. Friday, Jan. 23, at St. John’s Catholic Church in Kealakekua. Mass at 10 a.m. Burial to follow at Kona Memorial Park in Holualoa. Casual attire. Survived by son, James Mark (Roslyn) Thomas of Kona; stepchildren, Yolanda (Rick) Bautista of Honolulu, Alfred Estencion of Kona, Darren Estencion of Maui and Eldaine Barawis of Kailua-Kona; godchildren, Casey Keohuloa, Pikake Keohuloa and Trina Kauhaihao; three grandchildren; nieces, nephews, and cousins. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.

item.title: Shock and skepticism in world’s capitals after US seizes Maduro
item.description: BERLIN — Despite the long military buildup around Venezuela, the U.S. raid on Caracas, the capital, to capture President Nicolás Maduro and his wife produced initial reactions of shock, outrage and skepticism from international leaders, many of them troubled by an exercise of U.S. gunboat diplomacy.

item.title: Steves: Gibraltar is a bite of Britain in Spain
item.description: When in southern Spain, I can’t resist popping into the British colony of Gibraltar. Gibraltar is hardly signposted in Spain, as if Spain wishes the British colony didn’t exist. (Drivers follow highway signs to La Línea, the last Spanish town before the border.) But when you see that famous “Rock of Prudential” standing boldly above the sea, you know it’s here to stay.
item.source:markdown: When in southern Spain, I can’t resist popping into the British colony of Gibraltar. Gibraltar is hardly signposted in Spain, as if Spain wishes the British colony didn’t exist. (Drivers follow highway signs to La Línea, the last Spanish town before the border.) But when you see that famous “Rock of Prudential” standing boldly above the sea, you know it’s here to stay.

item.title: Madang reconnected to Ramu Grid after heroic effort by PNG Power Crews
item.description:
Residents of Madang are finally back on the grid following a grueling restoration effort by PNG Power Limited (PPL) teams who battled extreme weather conditions to repair the L605 transmission line.

The coastal town had been split from the main Ramu grid after heavy rains and severe flooding at the Assas bypass triggered a major system fault.

item.title: Major power failure plunges Highlands hubs into darkness
item.description:
A major fault on the main 66kV transmission line has left thousands of residents and businesses across the Highlands region without power, as PNG Power Limited (PPL) scrambles to stabilize the Ramu Grid.

The disruption occurred after Transmission Line 506, the primary link carrying electricity from Ramu through Goroka to the Highlands, tripped off. The outage has affected several provincial hubs, including: Kainantu, Goroka, Kundiawa, Kudjip, Mt. Hagen

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Major power failure plunges Highlands hubs into darkness appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/PNG-Power-Limited-PPL-scrambles-to-stabilize-the-Ramu-Grid.-FILE-PHOTOS.png?w=800)
A major fault on the main 66kV transmission line has left thousands of residents and businesses across the Highlands region without power, as PNG Power Limited (PPL) scrambles to stabilize the Ramu Grid.
The disruption occurred after **Transmission Line 506**, the primary link carrying electricity from Ramu through Goroka to the Highlands, tripped off. The outage has affected several provincial hubs, including: _Kainantu, Goroka, Kundiawa, Kudjip, Mt. Hagen_

item.title: Central Provincial Government moves to protect rural producers from market harassment
item.description:
The Central Provincial Government (CPG), led by Deputy Governor and Chairman for Law & Order, Desmond Baira, is initiating high-level meetings to address the systemic harassment of rural producers supplying the National Capital District (NCD).

Farmers, fishermen, and betelnut growers from Central Province report growing intimidation and extortion when transporting goods to major NCD hubs, including Gordons, Boroko, and Koki. A primary concern is the predatory behaviour of "middlemen" who demand unauthorised "carrying fees."

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Central Provincial Government moves to protect rural producers from market harassment appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/Central-Provincial-Government-moves-to-protect-rural-producers-from-market-harassment.png?w=800)
The Central Provincial Government (CPG), led by Deputy Governor and Chairman for Law & Order, Desmond Baira, is initiating high-level meetings to address the systemic harassment of rural producers supplying the National Capital District (NCD).
Farmers, fishermen, and betelnut growers from Central Province report growing intimidation and extortion when transporting goods to major NCD hubs, including Gordons, Boroko, and Koki. A primary concern is the predatory behaviour of "middlemen" who demand unauthorised "carrying fees."

And he declared his devotion to the cause and his willingness to die for it.

item.title: A study is retracted, renewing concerns about the weedkiller Roundup
item.description: In 2000, a landmark study claimed to set the record straight on glyphosate, a contentious weedkiller used on hundreds of millions of acres of farmland. The paper found that the chemical, the active ingredient in Roundup, wasn’t a human health risk despite evidence of a cancer link.

item.title: Mayor’s Cup revives touch rugby in West New Britain
item.description:
By ELIZABETH PINJWAI MAKIS

The revival of Touch Rugby in West New Britain Province (WNBP) has reached a turning point this week with the hosting of the inaugural Mayor’s Cup touch tournament. The tournament, which launched on Christmas Day, is being hailed as a critical "restart" for a sport that has remained largely dormant in the province for a decade.

item.title: Pacific Towing successfully refloats Coral Adventurer

item.title: Access Road to Water PNG washed out by heavy rain in Popondetta
item.description:
Heavy rainfall on New Year’s Eve has left the access road to the Water PNG facility in Popondetta severely damaged, creating significant hazards for motorists and pedestrians.

The damage was reportedly exacerbated by a blocked stormwater drain. According to local resident Mathew Malpaim, a discarded tyre was dumped into the drainage system, obstructing the natural flow of water.

item.title: Bradley Wak calls for unity in Dei District with major peace offering
item.description:
Two tribes in the Dei District of Western Highlands Province have participated in a major reconciliation ceremony to restore solidarity and peace ahead of the 2026 calendar year.

The event, hosted by intending candidate for the Dei Open by-election, Baffinu Bradley Wak, marked a formal reunion between the Prandak and Kinsibi Rangikrambo tribes. The ceremony was organized to encourage both groups to set aside past differences and live as neighbors in harmony.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Bradley Wak calls for unity in Dei District with major peace offering appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: ICCC confirms fuel price to increase commencing on January 8
item.description:
The Independent Consumer and Competition Commission (ICCC) has announced the increase in wholesale, retail, and drum-filling prices for petrol, diesel, and kerosene to be effective starting January 8, 2026.

The acting chief executive officer, Brian Ivosa, said the annual adjustments were in accordance with the determinations of the 2024 Petroleum Industry pricing review, applying in the five-year (2024-2029) regulatory period.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post ICCC confirms fuel price to increase commencing on January 8 appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Ela Murray International School brings holiday cheer to children at Port Moresby General Hospital
item.description:
The Ela Murray International School has extended the spirit of giving this festive season, delivering joy and comfort to young patients at Port Moresby General Hospital (PMGH).

As part of its Gift-a-Friend, Christmas and New Year Charity Drive, the school donated 250 gift bags filled with essential items and festive treats. The gifts, lovingly prepared by students and parents, were distributed across all five paediatric wards, ensuring children spending the holidays in hospital could share in the celebrations with their families.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Ela Murray International School brings holiday cheer to children at Port Moresby General Hospital appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Don re-signs Edene on a new two-year contract
item.description:
The Dons have handed their 2026 campaign a massive boost with the confirmation that star winger Edene Gebbie has committed his future to the club. The reigning Player of the Year has officially signed a new two-year contract extension, keeping him at the heart of the squad’s ambitious push for the play-offs.

The 30-year-old Papua New Guinea international proved to be a revelation last season, finishing the year with a remarkable strike rate of 25 tries in just 22 appearances. His decision to extend his stay is a significant statement of intent for the club as they look to build on the momentum of the previous season.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Don re-signs Edene on a new two-year contract appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Ok Tedi strengthens community safety with support to Water Police
item.description:
OK Tedi Mining Limited (OTML) has donated four 200-litre drums of zoom to the Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary (RPNGC) Water Police Directorate in Port Moresby.

The donation reaffirmed OTML’s commitment to community safety and law and order. The fuel support will enable the Water Police team to increase maritime patrols and maintain law and order across Fairfax Harbour, safeguarding it, the surrounding areas and the Motukea logistics corridor.

item.title: North Fly MP raises concerns over Ok Tedi mine’s environmental legacy
item.description:
Member for North Fly James Donald MP, has voiced urgent concerns regarding the ongoing environmental issues and the lack of proper consultation with local landowners concerning the future of Ok Tedi mine’s operations.

In a statement earlier this week, Mr. Donald highlighted that Ok Tedi Mining Limited (OTML) has failed to address persistent environmental degradation and has not secured the free and informed consent of the affected communities.

item.title: Minimum wage hike, ‘Green fee’ tax among Hawaii’s new 2026 laws
item.description: Hawaii’s minimum wage goes up $2 an hour today — to $16 from $14 — amid other new state laws in 2026 that include America’s first statewide tax increase aimed primarily at tourists to help adapt to climate change and reduce the risk of future wildfires.

item.title: Drugmakers raise US prices on 350 medicines despite pressure from Trump
item.description: NEW YORK — Drugmakers plan to raise U.S. prices on at least 350 branded medications including vaccines ‌against COVID, RSV and shingles and blockbuster cancer treatment Ibrance, even as the Trump administration pressures them for cuts, according to data provided exclusively by healthcare research firm 3 Axis Advisors.
item.source:markdown: NEW YORK — Drugmakers plan to raise U.S. prices on at least 350 branded medications including vaccines ‌against COVID, RSV and shingles and blockbuster cancer treatment Ibrance, even as the Trump administration pressures them for cuts, according to data provided exclusively by healthcare research firm 3 Axis Advisors.

item.title: Trump administration freezes child day care payments to Minnesota
item.description: Republican President Donald Trump’s administration has announced a freeze ‌on child day care payments to Democratic-led Minnesota, ramping up what the state’s governor had characterized as a political confrontation over immigration and allegations of widespread fraud in social services programs.

item.title: Justice Dept. is now said to be reviewing 5.2 million pages of Epstein files
item.description: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department is seeking to enlist about 400 lawyers to review roughly 5.2 million pages of Epstein files documents, an effort that is drawing in prosecutors who work on national security and criminal cases, and in U.S. attorneys’ offices in New York and Florida, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department is seeking to enlist about 400 lawyers to review roughly 5.2 million pages of Epstein files documents, an effort that is drawing in prosecutors who work on national security and criminal cases, and in U.S. attorneys’ offices in New York and Florida, according to people familiar with the matter.

item.title: Obituaries for January 1
item.description: Christopher Brian Herbold, 41, of Kailua-Kona died Oct. 9 in Kailua-Kona. He was born in Seguin, Texas. Services at a later date. Survived by partner, Angela Taft; children, Derick Herbold, Kaison Herbold, Capri Herbold, Marley Herbold and Charlee Herbold; mother, Tami (William Newberg) Herbold; father, Alfredo (Brenda) Sanchez Jr.; sisters, Kristen (Clint) Jahns and Ceira Sanchez; brother, AD Sanchez; grandparents, Margaret Herbold and Ruben Sanchez; a niece a nephew, aunts, uncles and cousins. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.

item.title: Call for accountability over the delayed and substandard Haku Road Project
item.description:
David Tupp, a senior Bougainvillean civil engineer and former Provincial Works Manager, is demanding answers from authorities and a contractor over the stalled and substandard condition of a key road project in the Haku Constituency.

The project in question is the 14.7-kilometre Pitono-Kesa road, a crucial segment of the Buka Ring Road.

item.title: Pavaia’i Elementary artwork displayed at the White House National Christmas Tree Exhibit
item.description:
By 
Samoa News staff
reporters@samoanews.com

Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA — December 19, 2025) Pavaia’i Elementary School has received national recognition through the America Celebrates display, as artwork created by students from Ms. Loimata Siona’s 4th grade class were selected for exhibition at the White House. The program features handcrafted ornaments representing every U.S. state, territory, and the District of Columbia, all showcased around the iconic National Christmas Tree.

The ornaments submitted by Ms. Siona’s elementary class were designed during the previous school year, reflecting the culture, pride, and unique identity of American Samoa.

Each year, the America Celebrates program provides students across the nation with an opportunity to represent their home state or territory through original artwork that becomes part of a holiday tradition in the nation’s capital.

 The National Christmas Tree, along with the accompanying state and territory ornaments, will remain on display at the White House through January 1, 2026.

Visitors from around the world will have the opportunity to admire the creativity, talent, and cultural expression of young artists from across the United States and its territories. 

Visit the nationaltree.org/ornaments/american-samoa/ to view the complete collection of the American Samoa state ornaments.

 

Section: 
Local News
Tags: 
White House National Christmas Tree Exhibit

[![American Samoa ornaments at White House](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/field/image/as_ornaments_at_white_hse.jpg?itok=ZuEtdBqA)](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_normal_image/public/field/image/as_ornaments_at_white_hse.jpg?itok=jgzamaVW)

item.title: Driving and parking on Malae o le Talu “no longer tolerated”
item.description:
By 
Samoa News staff
reporters@samoanews.com

Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA — The Governor’s Office has officially given notice that parking and driving on the Malae o le Talu will no longer be tolerated. However, there is “no teeth” to the notice, as no fines for the offense are posted and the question of enforcement arises, as the Department of Public Safety has been seen as one of the worst offenders — using the Malae as a parking zone for their vehicles.

In the notice posted on the Office of the Governor’s webpage and addressed to the Secretary of Samoan Affairs, CEOs, Presidents and Executive Directors of Authorities, Directors. Agency and Office Heads — it says in part, “This prohibition applies to all ASG employees, contractors, and agents operating government vehicles, regardless of purpose or duration.”

Effective immediately, the following measures are hereby implemented:

a)      All American Samoa Government (ASG) vehicles and privately owned and operated vehicles are strictly prohibited from driving or parking on the Malae. This prohibition applies to all ASG employees, contractors, and agents operating government vehicles, regardless of purpose or duration.

b)      The Department of Parks and Recreation shall provide technical assistance, resources, and operational support to the village Pulenu’u and Leoleo Nuu in their efforts to protect the Malae.

c)      All ASG personnel and privately owned vehicles must utilize designated or alternate parking areas in proximity to the Malae.

Emergency vehicles responding to actual emergencies may access the Malae only to the extent absolutely necessary to address the emergency situations.

All agency heads, directors, and supervisors are responsible for ensuring that employees under their supervision are informed of and comply with this directive.

Preserving the cultural, historical, and recreational use of the Malae is a matter of territorial significance and requires the full cooperation of all ASG personnel.

A memo, dated December 23, 2025, and signed by Governor Pulaali’i Nikolau Pula notes that “the Malae o le Talu (Malae) has been a central gathering place of profound historical, cultural, and ceremonial significance to the people of American Samoa for over 125 years, hosting village events, governmental functions, and community recreation.

“Vehicular traffic has severely damaged the Malae, compacting soil, destroying grass, and creating unsafe divots, hindering full use and enjoyment of this communal gathering place.”

Samoa News has published photos of the “No Parking” signs on the Malae, especially when the Governor’s Office moved into their new location at the newly renovated old ASB-ANZ Bank building — the Malae o le Talu is located directly across the street. Photos published also included the Department of Public Safety parking their vehicles on the Malae.

Section: 
Local News
Tags: 
Malae o le Talu
item.source:markdown:
[![No parking sign](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/field/image/img_9748.jpg?itok=G1licTF9)](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_normal_image/public/field/image/img_9748.jpg?itok=DXzBJoGx)

In the notice posted on the Office of the Governor’s webpage and addressed to the Secretary of Samoan Affairs, CEOs, Presidents and Executive Directors of Authorities, Directors. a) All American Samoa Government (ASG) vehicles and privately owned and operated vehicles are strictly prohibited from driving or parking on the Malae. This prohibition applies to all ASG employees, contractors, and agents operating government vehicles, regardless of purpose or duration.

item.title: PC Online Tidbits
item.description:
Seems PNG still will be walking into 2026 with more power blackouts, and water cuts. To add more value to our richness on this front,  now we also look largely blacked out on the satellite internet provider, Starlink’s, availability Map when we checked. There we are, the biggest blackest dot shaded in the region. All our teeny tiny neighbours in the Pacific shining bright like diamonds are part of more than 150 countries moving forward while we take a different path we anticipate with this.

The post PC Online Tidbits appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: The tiny Japanese island on the front lines of China’s feud
item.description: YONAGUNI ISLAND, Japan — As a lifelong resident of Yonaguni, a remote island that is Japan’s westernmost point, Himeyo Ukemasu remembers the distant days when life was measured by the bright stars, the tides and the ripening of mulberry trees.

item.title: Thieves drill into German bank vault and make off with millions
item.description: BERLIN — Thieves used the quiet Christmas period to drill their ​way into ‌the vault of a German retail bank ‌and make off with at least 10 million euros’ worth of money and valuables from customers’ deposit boxes, police said on Tuesday.
item.source:markdown: BERLIN — Thieves used the quiet Christmas period to drill their ​way into ‌the vault of a German retail bank ‌and make off with at least 10 million euros’ worth of money and valuables from customers’ deposit boxes, police said on Tuesday.

item.title: Court allows Trump-backed cuts to Planned Parenthood’s Medicaid funding in 22 states
item.description: BOSTON — A U.S. appeals court on Tuesday allowed President Donald Trump’s administration to enforce in several Democratic-led states a provision of his signature tax and domestic policy bill that deprives Planned Parenthood health centers that perform abortions of Medicaid funding.
item.source:markdown: BOSTON — A U.S. appeals court on Tuesday allowed President Donald Trump’s administration to enforce in several Democratic-led states a provision of his signature tax and domestic policy bill that deprives Planned Parenthood health centers that perform abortions of Medicaid funding.

item.title: Obituaries for December 31
item.description: Russell Y. Hatada, 74, of Hilo, died Dec. 9 at home. Born in Hilo, he was a retired baker for the former Robert’s Bakery. Private services held. Online condolences: www.homelanimemorialpark.com. Survived by daughter, Erin (Keith) Nacis of Hilo; sister, Cheryl Ferreira; sister-in-law, Lynn Hatada; two grandchildren; aunts, uncles, nieces and nephews. Arrangements by Homelani Memorial Park.
item.source:markdown: Russell Y. Hatada, 74, of Hilo, died Dec. 9 at home. Born in Hilo, he was a retired baker for the former Robert’s Bakery. Private services held. item.title: Crew paints Russian flag on tanker pursued by the US Coast Guard

item.description: KYIV — Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said on ‌Tuesday Kyiv was discussing with Washington a possible presence of U.S. troops in Ukraine as part of security guarantees, and also raised what he called a faked attack on Russian President Vladimir Putin’s residence.

item.title: China mandates 50% domestic equipment rule for chipmakers, sources say
item.description: SINGAPORE — China is requiring chipmakers to use at least 50% domestically made equipment for adding new capacity, three ‌people familiar with the matter said, as Beijing pushes to build a self-sufficient semiconductor supply chain.

item.title: Gaza aid groups face suspensions under new Israeli rules
item.description: More than three dozen humanitarian groups will have their authorizations to operate in the Gaza Strip suspended on Jan. 1 and will have to clear out by March after failing to comply with new registration rules, Israel’s Ministry of Diaspora Affairs said on Tuesday.

item.title: Looking forward together to all the possibilities for a wonderful new year
item.description:
By 
Samoa News staff
reporters@samoanews.com

Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA — In this beautiful photo, Congresswoman Uifa’atali Aumua Amata remembered our loved ones far away due to military service, collegiate studies, or careers in the states.

“May God especially bless and each of them and these families, with ‘many happy returns’ to our island home. This Christmas, we keep our Toa o Samoa especially in our prayers – thank you to each one for your service and sacrifice! Just this week, Congress sent next year’s 3.8 percent pay raise for our military to the President to be signed into law, as part of a busy December.

“We look forward together to all the possibilities for a wonderful new year. May each of us celebrate this special season with joyful and charitable hearts.”

Local News

item.title: Ring in the New Year with promises of renewal, reflection and hope
item.description:
By 
Samoa News staff
reporters@samoanews.com

 

Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA — In observance of the New Year holiday, Governor Pulaali’i Nikolau Pula has announced that the government will officially take two days off — Thursday, January 1, 2026 and Friday, January 2nd. However, Wednesday, while not a holiday, will be a half day, with an early release from work at 12p.m.

As per usual on a government holiday all government offices will be closed, and normal operations will be suspended. Employees of the American Samoa Government who are not required to perform essential services shall be excused from duty. Those employees whose duties are essential and are required to work on these holidays shall receive holiday compensation in accordance with applicable laws and regulations.

“Government operations shall resume under normal business hours on Monday, January 5th 2026.

“The New Year marks a time of renewal, reflection, and hope as we look ahead to new opportunities and responsibilities. It is also a moment to give thanks for God’s guidance and blessings throughout the past year. Employees are encouraged to spend this time with family and loved ones, reflect on the yer past, and prepare for the year ahead with renewed purpose, unity, and commitment in serving our community.”

Governor Puaali’i extends his sincere appreciation for their continued service and dedication to the people of the Territory. “May the New Year bring you good health, success, and prosperity.

Samoa News should note that the governor is currently off island, with no return date currently announced.

The US Post Office Service will be closed New Year’s Day, returning on Friday, Jan. 2nd, as per normal federal holiday.

The Territorial Bank of American Samoa (TBAS) will close early at 12 pm, on Wednesday, December 31, 2025; on Thursday, Jan 1, 2026 it will be closed; and, it will be open on Friday, Jan. 2nd for full service.

Don’t forget American Samoa is the last “inhabited” country to ring in the New Year — if you want to see the last sunset of 2025 in the Territory, take a ride out to Poloa. On the other hand, if you want to experience the first New Year celebration in the world, you need to fly to Samoa, with the holidays experiencing some of the the busiest flight times for the inter-island airlines.

For StarKist Samoa its cannery shutdown continues for the Christmas and New Year holidays. The shutdown allows for major maintenance work and prepares the cannery for the new year, with the company slated to begin production of pet food in 2026.

With more than 80% of the cannery workforce of more than 2,000 being from Samoa, they have headed home for the holidays. The cannery did arrange for a charter of the Lady Samoa ferry to take its employees to Samoa during Christmas week. It’s unknown if a return-trip ferry has been chartered.

The company’s first day of production for 2026 is scheduled for Monday, Jan. 5th.

Usually New Year in the Territory highlights its NY Eve’s church services before the bars begin to fill to ring in the brand new year.

On New Year Day, look for family or company barbecues at the public beaches and parks. Most grocery stores will be open, with specialty stores and companies usually closing on that day, with all returning to full service on Friday.

According to the National Weather Service- Pago Pago, the weather forecast for New Year’s Day is partly cloudy, isolated showers, highs in the upper 80s, and variable winds up to 10 mph. It looks like mostly a sunny day.

From Thursday night through to Friday, its still partly cloudy however, scattered showers are forecast.

Friday night through Sunday, the weather is mostly cloudy with numerous showers — definitely expect rain throughout the weekend.

For the public’s safety, the police are continuing their Enforcement initiative that began about 2 weeks ago, marking the beginning of a focused effort to enhance road safety during the busy festive season. 

Commissioner of Public Safety Taaga Saite Moliga announced the Enforcement initiative noting the deployment of strategically placed roadblocks throughout the community to identify and evaluate drivers suspected of being under the influence of alcohol or drugs. He noted these roadblocks would be strategically placed in response to real-time traffic patterns, focusing on high-traffic areas during peak travel periods to maximize visibility and effectiveness.

The DPS is maintaining its Holiday Enforcement program, through Saturday, January 3, 2026. 

Samoa News will have an issue tomorrow, December 31st, New Year’s eve day and will be off on Thursday, Jan 1st and Friday, Jan. 2nd, returning on Monday, Jan 5th, 2026.

Happy New Year — American Samoa. Be safe, and with God’s grace may we ring in the New Year remembering to be kind to one another.

Section: 
Local News
Tags: 
NEW YEAR 2026

[![poloa sunset](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/field/image/poloa_sunset_3270web_0.jpg?itok=_oKthwAl)](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_normal_image/public/field/image/poloa_sunset_3270web_0.jpg?itok=Rexg5oDc)

item.title: Australian tourist says PNG visit was memorable but ended early
item.description:
An Australian tourist says her visit to Papua New Guinea was memorable but ended earlier than planned after the cruise vessel Coral Adventurer ran aground off the Finschhafen coast.

“We visited some remote islands in Papua New Guinea and found everyone extremely friendly and welcoming,” the tourist said. “We loved visiting the villages, meeting the children, and seeing the schools. The snorkelling was amazing, with beautiful reefs and fish. Unfortunately, our adventure ended due to the vessel incident.”

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Australian tourist says PNG visit was memorable but ended early appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Peace hopes dented as Russia says Ukraine tried to attack Putin residence
item.description: MOSCOW/KYIV — Russia accused Ukraine on Monday ​of trying to attack President Vladimir Putin’s residence and ‌vowed retaliation, providing no evidence for a claim Kyiv dismissed as baseless and aimed at derailing arduous peace talks.
item.source:markdown: MOSCOW/KYIV — Russia accused Ukraine on Monday ​of trying to attack President Vladimir Putin’s residence and ‌vowed retaliation, providing no evidence for a claim Kyiv dismissed as baseless and aimed at derailing arduous peace talks.

item.title: Green appoints Kanaka‘ole acting director of DLNR
item.description: Gov. Josh Green announced Monday Deputy Director Ryan Kanaka‘ole will serve as acting chair and director of Department of Land and Natural Resources, effective immediately, while Chair Dawn Chang is out on medical leave.
item.source:markdown: Gov. Josh Green announced Monday Deputy Director Ryan Kanaka‘ole will serve as acting chair and director of Department of Land and Natural Resources, effective immediately, while Chair Dawn Chang is out on medical leave.

item.title: US strikes drug boat loading facility in Venezuela, Trump says
item.description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — President Donald Trump said on Monday that the U.S. had “hit” an area in Venezuela where boats are loaded with drugs, marking the first known time Washington has carried out land operations in Venezuela since a pressure campaign began against President Nicolas Maduro’s government.
item.source:markdown: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — President Donald Trump said on Monday that the U.S. had “hit” an area in Venezuela where boats are loaded with drugs, marking the first known time Washington has carried out land operations in Venezuela since a pressure campaign began against President Nicolas Maduro’s government.

item.title: The world wants more ube. Philippine farmers are struggling to keep up
item.description: BENGUET PROVINCE, Philippines — In New York City, people line up outside a bakery before it opens to buy a brioche doughnut whose glaze shines a startling purple. In Paris, people sip purple-colored lattes with a mellow, nutty scent. In Melbourne, Australia, a purple tinge gives hot cross buns a gentle sweetness.
item.source:markdown: BENGUET PROVINCE, Philippines — In New York City, people line up outside a bakery before it opens to buy a brioche doughnut whose glaze shines a startling purple. In Paris, people sip purple-colored lattes with a mellow, nutty scent. In Melbourne, Australia, a purple tinge gives hot cross buns a gentle sweetness.

item.title: Trump warns Iran of possible strike, urges Hamas to disarm after meeting Netanyahu
item.description: PALM BEACH, Fla. — President Donald Trump said on Monday ‌the United States could support another major strike on Iran were it to resume rebuilding its ballistic missile or nuclear weapons ‌programs and warned Hamas of severe consequences if it does not disarm.
item.source:markdown: PALM BEACH, Fla. — President Donald Trump said on Monday ‌the United States could support another major strike on Iran were it to resume rebuilding its ballistic missile or nuclear weapons ‌programs and warned Hamas of severe consequences if it does not disarm.

item.title: Obituaries for December 30
item.description: Perfectua Castanero Babiera, 88, of Hilo died Dec. 1 at Life Care Center of Hilo. Born in the Philippines, she was a sorter for Mauna Loa Macadamia Nut Co. and member of the St. Joseph Catholic Church. Visitation 4-6 p.m. Thursday, Jan. 8, at Dodo Mortuary Chapel. Wake service at 6 p.m. Visitation again 8-9:30 a.m. Friday, Jan. 9, at St. Joseph Catholic Church. Mass at 9;30 a.m. Burial to follow at Homelani Memorial Park, Ilima Section. Survived by niece/hanai daughter, Joceyln (Albert Lagronio) Lazaga of Hilo; two grandchildren. nieces and nephews. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.
